a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to fundamental principle violations affecting millions. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating as company showed negligence. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as company implemented some compliance measures. Other aggravating factors included financial benefits derived from unlawful processing.

a2_authority_name: National Commission for Information Technology and Civil Liberties
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for data transmission; DPA found consent required for electronic prospecting; Legal basis discussion focused on validity of consent collection methods.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2020 on consent within the meaning of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: CALOGA processed prospect data for electronic marketing without valid consent; DPA found breaches of storage limitation, lawful basis, and French e-privacy rules; Company failed to verify consent validity from partners and implemented problematic withdrawal mechanisms.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Art 83(2) factors discussed; Nature/gravity/duration and intentional/negligent character were aggravating; Financial advantage from violations was aggravating; Company's ceased trading was considered.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller invoked legitimate interests for public safety; DPA found information outdated and no longer justified; ordered removal under right to erasure
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria of the Right to be Forgotten in the search engines cases under the GDPR;guidelines on the implementation of the Court of Justice of the European Union judgment on Google Spain and Inc v. Agencia Española de Protección de Datos (AEPD) and Mario Costeja González C-131/12
a75_case_summary: Applicant requested removal of search results linking to outdated wanted notice; Google invoked legitimate interests for public safety; DPA found information no longer socially relevant as warrant expired in 2011; ordered removal under Article 17 right to erasure
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The legal basis was not assessed; the decision focused solely on data minimization principles regardless of processing basis
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 4/2019 on built-in and default data protection pursuant to Article 25
a75_case_summary: A Finnish municipality collected bank account numbers from all students for scholarship payments, though only some students receive scholarships. The Deputy Data Protection Commissioner found this violated Article 5(1)(c) data minimization principle as collecting data from all students "just to be sure" was unnecessary. The controller was issued a reprimand and ordered to bring processing into compliance and delete unnecessarily collected account numbers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on data subject rights - Right of access;Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data by video equipment
a75_case_summary: The Police University of Applied Sciences refused to provide video recordings of a screening test to a data subject, citing Article 15(4) GDPR protection of others' rights. The DPA found the controller failed to demonstrate specific harm to others' rights and ordered provision of the recordings. The DPA emphasized that Article 15(4) requires case-specific assessment, not general claims of potential harm.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA investigated municipal registrar's failure to have data processing agreement with website management company that processed student data through contact forms. The registrar lacked contractual documentation required under Article 28(3) GDPR but had since ceased using the processor. The DPA issued a reprimand but no fine due to the defendant's public administration status.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found parking company X Oy violated data minimization principle when technical failures in parking machines forced customers to provide phone numbers for SMS receipts instead of offering paper receipts; The DPA determined phone numbers were not necessary for receipt provision and the company failed to implement adequate technical measures; The controller was ordered to bring processing into compliance with GDPR principles; The case originated from a data subject complaint about mandatory phone number collection for receipts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Officer
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no processing criterion was defined; DPA found no legal basis assessed under Articles 6 and 9; Processing would require both Article 6 basis and Article 9 exception for health data
a75_case_summary: Housing association required residents to report COVID-19 infections to property manager for cleaning efficiency; DPA found no legal basis assessed under Articles 6 and 9 for processing health data; Violated data minimization principle and built-in data protection requirements; Warning issued as no actual data collected
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed there was a GDPR agreement dated 24 May 2018, but the DPA found it did not fulfill the requirements of Article 28(3) GDPR. The DPA determined no proper data processing agreement existed between the parties.
a75_case_summary: Y Oy processed personal data as a processor for XX Oy in telemarketing operations without a proper data processing agreement as required by Article 28(3) GDPR. The DPA found Y Oy neglected its obligation to draw up such an agreement. While the breach was considered serious, no fine was imposed due to Y Oy's ceased operations, low turnover, and pending bankruptcy proceedings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of Y Oy's business and knowing failure to comply as aggravating factors. Mitigating factors included Y Oy's ceased operations, low turnover (€839.33), and pending bankruptcy application. The sanction panel ultimately found imposing a fine would be disproportionate.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found a parking management company violated data minimization principles by displaying property addresses on parking permits. The controller argued address information was necessary for parking enforcement, but the DPA determined numeric identifiers could achieve the same purpose without revealing addresses. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered the controller to bring processing into compliance by removing address information from parking permits.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Applicant sought access to full OP bonus account information including wife's bonus data. DPA found no right of access exists due to bank secrecy protecting wife's financial status. Disclosure would adversely affect wife's rights under Article 15(4) GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness and informed choice; controller later stated legal obligation but did not specify which; DPA found legal basis not transparently informed
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA issued reprimand to municipal early childhood education provider for failing to transparently inform parents about purpose and legal basis of processing personal data collected via COVID-19 questionnaire; Controller initially claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness and clarity; Purpose remained unclear whether for childcare arrangements, payment refunds, or both
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed public task as legal basis for participatory budgeting service. The DPA did not explicitly invalidate this legal basis but found violations of Articles 25 and 32 regarding data protection by design and security measures.
a75_case_summary: A municipal participatory budgeting service made user profiles publicly searchable and visible, exposing approximately 160,000 individuals' names and activity data. The DPA found violations of Articles 25(2) (data protection by design and by default) and 32(1) (security of processing) as profiles were unnecessarily accessible to unlimited persons. The controller received a reprimand but no fine, as corrective measures had already been implemented.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of the infringement as aggravating (profiles publicly accessible without limitation) and the controller's remedial actions as mitigating (deleted profiles, removed search function). Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests for processing purchase data throughout customer relationship; DPA found this violated storage limitation principle as retention period was not purpose-specific and could extend for decades.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 4/2019 on built-in and default data protection pursuant to Article 25 Version 2.0;EDPB Guidelines 02/2021 on virtual assistants controlled by voice commands Version 2.0
a75_case_summary: Kesko Oyj processed customer purchase data through its Plussa loyalty program, storing detailed purchase information throughout the customer relationship without purpose-specific retention periods. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(c), 5(1)(e), 25(1) and 25(2) GDPR regarding data minimization, storage limitation, and data protection by design/default. The controller was ordered to define purpose-specific retention periods and delete/anonymize data exceeding these periods.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors but did not impose a fine. Factors considered aggravating included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, technical/organizational measures, and categories of data affected. The sanctions panel found mitigating factors in that storage periods had not yet become disproportionately long compared to industry practice.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent and legitimate interest; DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance; No legal basis established for location data processing
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for consent according to Regulation 2016/679 05/2020
a75_case_summary: University processed employee location data via mobile app for time stamping; DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 and violation of data minimization principle; Processing ban imposed and €25,000 fine for violations of Articles 5 and 6
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Art 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/duration, negligence, data categories, vulnerable position; Mitigating: cooperation, no previous violations, no financial gain; Fine reduced due to non-profit educational mission

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing based on patient consent and various regulations; DPA found no valid legal basis identified for processing patient data in step 1; Controller failed to specify which regulation served as legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA issued warning regarding planned healthcare profiling system; Controller failed to identify automated individual decisions under Article 22 for patients not selected for closer examination; Controller also lacked legal basis under Articles 6 and 9 for processing patient data in risk model development phase; DPA found processing likely violated GDPR principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Travel agency processed visa applications via unencrypted HTTP protocol, storing personal data including passport numbers on open web server. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 17(1), 25(1), and 32(1)-(2) GDPR. Company declared bankrupt during proceedings but group structure considered for fine allocation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, negligence, no mitigation actions, inadequate technical measures, no cooperation, passport data risk. Mitigating: no special category data. Neutral: no previous infringements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary to comply with legal obligations (Art 6(1)(c)). The DPA found this valid for collecting personal identity numbers under Section 29(2) of the Data Protection Act for fee recovery purposes.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA addressed a complaint about the Supreme Court requiring personal identity numbers for billing document requests. The DPA found it lacked competence over judicial document disclosure functions but had competence over fee collection processing. The Court was found to have legal basis for processing identity numbers under national law for fee recovery purposes, but was asked to reassess risks regarding potential disclosure of requesters' information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A data subject complained about a debt collection agency retaining personal data beyond necessary periods. The agency claimed retention was justified under accounting and debt collection laws. The Assistant Data Protection Officer found that only accounting-related data could be retained beyond 5 years, and ordered deletion of non-accounting data like emails.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligation under Motor Insurance Act; DPA found the interpretation overly broad and violating minimization principles; Controller must limit data collection to what is strictly necessary for compensation cases
a75_case_summary: Finnish Motor Insurance Center systematically requested full patient visit records instead of targeted statements for compensation cases; DPA found this violated data minimization, reasonableness, and default data protection principles; Controller claimed legal basis under Motor Insurance Act but DPA found interpretation overly broad; Fine imposed due to systematic nature, focus on health data, and long duration of violation
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, lack of mitigation actions, inadequate technical measures, and focus on sensitive health data; No mitigating factors identified; Cooperation was neutral as it was statutory obligation

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(a) and (c) but the DPA did not evaluate legal bases, focusing instead on principles violations.
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA found a municipal education authority violated GDPR principles by making students' personal data (names, roles, email addresses, schools, classes) visible in email address books across all city schools. The controller failed to demonstrate necessity for such wide visibility. The DPA issued a reprimand and compliance order to limit data visibility to necessary contexts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature/gravity (widespread children's data exposure), inadequate technical measures, and sensitive data categories as aggravating factors for the violation.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Supervisor
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A patient requested access to X-ray and MRI images from a hospital district, which charged €25 fee citing hospital practice. The DPA found the hospital violated Articles 12(5), 15(1) and 15(3) GDPR by charging for first copies of personal data. The DPA ordered the hospital to comply with the data subject's request and bring processing operations into compliance with GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligations; DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(f), 6(1), and 9(2) GDPR; Service failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure lawful processing.
a75_case_summary: The National Health Service violated GDPR by processing health data using only personal codes as selection criteria in the E-health system, leading to disclosure of incorrect health information when an orphan's court provided wrong personal code. DVI found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(f), 6(1), 9(2), 24(1), and 32(1)(b) due to inadequate technical and organizational measures. The Service was ordered to review its practices and implement better security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DVI considered mitigating factors: the Orphan's Court provided incorrect information, no data subject complaints were received, and the Service recognized the need for additional selection criteria. Aggravating factors included inadequate technical measures and special category data involved. The violation severity was reduced by these mitigating circumstances.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Latvian DPA conducted preventive inspection of vehicle rental companies with Lithuanian and Estonian authorities. SIA Fitsypro failed to provide requested information for DVI's supervisory tasks despite multiple requests sent to legal address. DPA found violation of Article 58(1)(e) GDPR for non-cooperation with supervisory authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/duration as aggravating; intentional character as aggravating; no cooperation as aggravating; no previous infringements as mitigating; financial situation as mitigating. Fine reduced from €14,787.78 to €1,000 due to risk of insolvency and continued illegal behavior.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed audio recording was based on Cabinet Regulation No. 369 requirements. The DPA found this legal basis invalid as the regulation only requires recording communications through communication means, not general audio recording via CCTV. The processing was found unlawful under Article 6(1).
a75_case_summary: SIA "QUANTRUM" conducted audio recording via CCTV in security control center claiming legal basis under Cabinet Regulation No. 369. DPA found the regulation only requires recording communications through communication means, not general audio recording. The processing violated Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(c) and 6(1) as it was excessive and without proper legal basis.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered SIA's remedial actions (terminating employee, deleting material, reviewing measures) as mitigating when choosing corrective measures over fines. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Latvian DPA fined SIA SOAAR €800 for failing to provide requested information during an inspection. The company had previously been fined for the same violation. The DPA found the company received requests via official electronic address but failed to respond within deadlines. The company eventually provided the information, which was considered a mitigating factor.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered previous similar violation as aggravating and eventual provision of information as mitigating. No systematic discussion of Article 83(2) factors was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed contract performance as legal basis but DPA found processing occurred without valid legal basis under Article 6(1) as contracts were not properly approved and identity verification was insufficient.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Tet violated GDPR by providing telecom services without proper contract confirmation and identity verification, processing personal data without legal basis, transferring data to debt collectors without validation, disclosing data to third parties via customer portal, and comparing new customer data with existing database without proper safeguards. DPA found intentional violations due to inadequate risk assessment and imposed €1.2M fine after considering aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: intentional nature, inadequate technical measures, previous infringements. Mitigating: cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage. Neutral: categories of data affected, manner infringement became known. Fine was adjusted downward from initial calculation based on proportionality assessment.

a36_legal_basis_summary: DEPO claimed consent as legal basis for processing personal data for additional services. DPA found consent invalid as it was not freely given since customers could not receive services without consenting. DPA indicated processing should be based on appropriate legal bases like contract performance or legal obligation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines 05/2020 for consent in accordance with the Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: DEPO required customers to obtain DEPO cards and consent to excessive personal data processing for unrelated purposes to access additional services. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a),(b),(c) and invalid consent under Article 6(1)(a). The fine was reduced from €4.37M to €17,495 considering mitigating factors including DEPO's retail nature, negligence rather than intent, cooperation, and efforts to improve compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature and duration of violation. Mitigating factors included negligence rather than intent, actions to mitigate damage, technical measures taken, no previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and other circumstances like Covid-19 impact. The fine was significantly reduced based on proportionality assessment.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Latvian DPA fined online store EUR 15,000 for inadequate privacy policy information. The DPA found the information was not in easy-to-understand language and provided non-systematically, violating Article 13 transparency requirements. The store cooperated with authorities and remedied deficiencies. The penalty was appealed to court.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered cooperation with authorities and remediation of deficiencies as mitigating factors. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal bases under Article 6(1)(c) and (e) for processing insolvency data and documents from the Enterprise Register. The DPA found these invalid as no legal obligation or public task mandate existed for the controller. The DPA also invalidated Article 6(1)(f) as the controller's interests did not prevail over data subjects' rights.
a75_case_summary: SIA Lursoft IT published personal data from Enterprise Register documents and historical insolvency records beyond legal limits. The DPA found violations of Article 5(1)(a),(b),(c) and Article 6(1) for lacking legal basis. The controller continued processing despite warnings. A €65,000 fine was imposed with an order to bring processing into compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Azienda Ospedaliero Universitaria Integrata di Verona
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Hospital employees improperly accessed health records of colleague-patients out of "mere curiosity" using unattended workstations. The DPA found inadequate security measures violated Article 5(1)(f) integrity/confidentiality. Despite self-reporting and corrective actions, the hospital was fined €30,000 for failing to implement proper access controls to sensitive health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity of breach involving health data, intentional conduct by employees, inadequate security measures. Mitigating: self-reporting violations, cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage. Neutral: No factors were explicitly neutral.

a2_authority_name: GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the public task legal basis (Article 6(1)(e)) valid for processing health data related to electronic medical prescriptions under the National Health Service, as the processing is necessary for the performance of tasks carried out in the public interest.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA issued an opinion on a draft decree from the Ministry of Economy and Finance regarding electronic medical prescription delivery methods. The DPA expressed favorable opinion on the draft decree which extends dematerialized prescriptions to additional categories and identifies alternative delivery channels to paper reminders. The opinion addresses COVID-19 emergency measures allowing immediate implementation of alternative delivery methods while ensuring data protection compliance. The DPA emphasized the need for uniform national implementation with adequate security measures for health data processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Municipality claimed legal basis under Italian transparency laws (Legislative Decree 33/2013 and 50/2016) requiring publication of administrative acts. The DPA found these laws did not justify publishing the full summons containing personal data or disclosing the complainant's name in the resolution, violating data minimization principles.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative acts and documents, carried out for the purpose of publicity and transparency on the web by public entities and other obliged entities
a75_case_summary: Municipality published resolution appointing legal counsel and full court summons containing complainant's personal data on its website. DPA found violation of data minimization principle (Article 5(1)(c)) and lack of legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) and (e). Municipality removed data after complaint. Fine reduced due to cooperation, remediation, first violation, and regulatory uncertainties.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature of data disclosed. Mitigating: duration less than one year, negligent character, actions to mitigate damage, technical measures, no previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and other factors including regulatory uncertainties and immediate remediation.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent for marketing but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of clarity and transparency in collection method; DPA noted controller requested consent without actually conducting marketing activities initially
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Iliad Italia violated GDPR principles regarding transparency in consent collection for marketing purposes; inadequate security measures for traffic data storage; and insufficient confidentiality protections in SIM registration kiosks. The company received an €800,000 fine primarily for traffic data violations, with additional reprimands and corrective orders. DPA considered the wide scope affecting 3 million users and negligent approach as aggravating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: wide scope affecting 3M users; seriousness of traffic data violations; negligent responsibility; poor cooperation; inadequate technical measures. Mitigating: corrective actions taken; significant financial losses in 2018. Neutral: inspection discovery method.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for legal obligation/public task under accounting regulations; the DPA found no specific legal provision authorized online disclosure of personal data; the DPA determined the processing lacked suitable regulatory conditions for lawful processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for the purpose of advertising and transparency on the web by public entities and other obliged entities
a75_case_summary: The Campania Region published personal data (names and residence) of two individuals relating to a debt owed by the Region on its institutional website without proper legal basis. The DPA found violations of data minimization principles and lack of suitable regulatory authorization for online disclosure. The Region promptly obscured the data upon notification but was fined €4,000 for the unlawful processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered duration of disclosure aggravating; negligent character, mitigation actions, cooperation, technical measures, and no previous violations as mitigating; data categories as neutral. Most Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Istituto Comprensivo Statale di Uggiano La Chiesa
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for legal obligation/public task under Article 6(1)(c) and (e). The DPA found no suitable legal basis for dissemination as Italian law requires specific legal provisions for public disclosure, which were absent.
a75_case_summary: Italian school posted lists containing minors' personal data (names, birthdates, addresses, phone numbers) on school entrance door. DPA found violation of data minimization and lawfulness principles, and absence of legal basis for public disclosure. Fine imposed was reduced due to limited duration, cooperation, and remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: vulnerability of minors. Mitigating: limited duration, culpable nature, cooperation with authority, remedial actions, no previous violations. Neutral: not specified.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: National Institute of Social Security - Provincial Directorate of Brescia
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA fined INPS Brescia €5000 for failing to respond to DPA's information request. Case originated from data subject's access request complaint. DPA found violation of Article 157 of Italian Data Protection Code for non-compliance with investigative powers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered culpable nature and staff shortages as aggravating factors, but no previous violations as mitigating. Fine determined as effective, proportionate and dissuasive.

a2_authority_name: The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found it invalid due to imbalance between data subject and public authority. DPA determined legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) and public task (Art 6(1)(e)) as valid bases for processing under specific sector regulations governing public competitions.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent pursuant to EU Regulation 2016/679 - WP 259;Opinion 2/2017 on the processing of data in the workplace, adopted by the Working Group art.29 adopted on 8 June 2017, WP 249
a75_case_summary: Hospital used third-party platform for public competition management. Platform exposed candidates' personal data including health information for 25 days due to inadequate security. DPA found violations of information obligations, controller-processor relationship regulation, legal basis requirements, data security, and prohibition on health data dissemination. Fine imposed considering first-time violation and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered sensitivity of health data and 25-day duration as aggravating. Cooperation with authority and reliance on contractor's assurances were mitigating. No previous violations considered mitigating. Fine reduced due to first application phase of GDPR.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legitimate interest for fraud prevention; DPA found no legitimate interest assessment conducted and invalidated all claimed legal bases; Processing lacked proper legal basis under employment context.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Concentrix violated GDPR by requiring call center employees to display personal health items (medicines, medical devices, tampons) on desks without containers. Company policy from June-July 2019 forced visibility of sensitive items, violating data minimization and lawful processing principles. DPA rejected company's legitimate interest claim for fraud prevention, finding no proper assessment conducted.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration affecting 253 employees, negligent conduct, special category data involved. Mitigating: comprehensive cooperation with authority, no specific precedents. Neutral: absence of previous infringements. Economic conditions considered based on 2019 revenues.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued provisional restriction order against TikTok under Article 66 urgent procedure due to serious concerns about age verification methods protecting minors. The order prohibits processing data of users in Italy without absolute certainty of age compliance. This emergency measure follows TikTok's failure to respond to initial inquiries and media reports of child fatalities linked to platform usage.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Azienda Unità Sanitaria Locale Toscana Sud Est
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis for processing health data; DPA found consent valid but information provided to data subjects was deficient; Key reasoning was that processing required consent as it created health risk profiles separate from treatment purposes.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) and determining whether processing is likely to result in a high risk
a75_case_summary: Tuscan health authority processed patient health data through initiative healthcare model involving GPs; DPA found multiple GDPR violations including inadequate security measures, deficient information provision, lack of impact assessment, and improper processor designation; Fine imposed considering both aggravating factors (health data sensitivity, security failures) and mitigating factors (cooperation, remedial actions).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: nature/gravity of infringement, categories of data affected, technical measures; Mitigating: actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, manner infringement became known; Neutral: none specifically mentioned.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was outside GDPR scope as employees processed their own data; DPA found processing fell under GDPR and lacked appropriate legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) and Article 9(2)(b)
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA investigated Enna Provincial Health Authority for implementing biometric fingerprint system for employee attendance monitoring. Authority claimed processing fell outside GDPR scope as employees processed their own data. DPA found processing constituted biometric data processing under GDPR controller responsibility, violating Article 5(1)(a) lawfulness principle and lacking appropriate legal basis under Articles 6(1)(c) and 9(2)(b).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: The Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Ministry claimed processing was based on public task under a directorial decree. The DPA found the decree lacked regulatory nature and was not properly authorized by primary legislation, making it an invalid legal basis for dissemination of personal data online.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for the purpose of advertising and transparency on the web by public entities and other obliged entities
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA fined the Ministry of Economic Development €75,000 for publishing personal data of over 5,000 managers online without proper legal basis. The Ministry published names, tax codes, emails and full CVs containing additional personal data on its website. The DPA found violations of data protection principles including lawfulness, purpose limitation and data minimization, as well as delayed DPO appointment.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating factors included the Ministry's cooperation, good faith assessment, limited duration of violation (30 days), and prompt response to data subject requests. The nature of the violation was considered culpable but not intentional. The lack of proper technical measures was considered aggravating.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA opinion on civic access request for COVID-19 school data; Committee requested detailed health data on pupils including isolation/quarantine cases and test results; DPA found disclosure would violate health data protection prohibitions under Italian transparency law; Data could enable identification of minors when combined with other information available in small school communities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed data collection was part of medical treatment process under Article 9(2)(h). The DPA found the collection did not have the concrete purpose of evaluating therapy but rather to refuse service, violating data minimization principles.
a75_case_summary: A dentist collected HIV status information from a patient during initial consultation through a questionnaire. The DPA found this violated Article 5 principles as the data collection was not relevant to the purposes claimed (treatment evaluation) but rather used to refuse service. The processing concerned special category health data without proper justification.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature of data (health/HIV) was aggravating; prejudicial consequences to data subject were aggravating; cooperation was mitigating; violation was not culpable (aggravating). The fine was set at €20,000 considering effectiveness, proportionality and dissuasiveness.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the violation was due to a software bug and that the GP was bound by professional secrecy. The DPA found the processing lacked legal basis and violated explicit requests for obscuration, constituting unlawful processing of special category data.
a75_case_summary: The Local Health Authority of Romagna transmitted health data (voluntary termination of pregnancy) to GPs despite patients' explicit obscuration requests due to a software bug. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(f), 9 GDPR and Article 75 of Italian Code. A €120,000 fine was imposed considering the sensitive nature of data but mitigating factors like cooperation and technical error.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity/duration, categories of data affected, previous infringements. Mitigating: absence of intent, actions to mitigate damage, technical measures taken, cooperation, first application period. The fine was reduced considering these mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Provincial Health Services Agency of Trento
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed the processing was due to an IT error in the publication routine. The DPA found the processing lacked a suitable legal basis and violated patients' explicit requests for obscuration, particularly for special category data related to pregnancy termination.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the subject of the Health Dossier - 4 June 2015
a75_case_summary: The Provincial Health Services Agency of Trento disclosed 293 health documents to general practitioners despite patients having exercised their right to obscuration. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (f) and Article 9 due to lack of legal basis for processing special category health data. The controller attributed the incident to an IT error but had previously been sanctioned for similar health data processing issues.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed multiple Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature of special category data, previous infringements, and technical measures deficiencies. Mitigating factors included the unintentional nature, immediate corrective actions, high cooperation, and the manner the authority became aware through the controller's own breach notification.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a.
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary to fulfill a legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c). The DPA found this legal basis valid for whistleblowing processing as it fulfills obligations under Italian whistleblowing legislation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default;Guidelines concerning the impact assessment on data protection as well as criteria to establish whether a treatment may present a high risk pursuant to Regulation 2016/679 WP 248
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found violations in Bologna Airport's whistleblowing system security measures. The airport used HTTP protocol instead of HTTPS for data transport, failed to encrypt stored data, and logged access to the whistleblowing application in firewall logs. The DPA determined these deficiencies violated integrity/confidentiality principles and data protection by design/default requirements, despite the airport's cooperation and remediation efforts post-inspection.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the sensitive nature of whistleblowing data and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included the company's cooperation, remediation efforts, first-time violation status, and economic difficulties due to COVID-19. The small number of data subjects involved was considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Medicina & Lavoro s.r.l. violated Articles 12 and 15 GDPR by failing to properly respond to data subject access requests. The company provided an inadequate response to the first request and no response to the second request regarding health surveillance data. The DPA imposed a €4,000 fine considering the nature of rights violations, prolonged duration, but also cooperation and absence of previous infringements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; cooperation was mitigating; previous infringements absence was mitigating; data categories (health) was aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Ruian cultural club violated GDPR through non-compliant video surveillance system. Cameras captured public areas including sidewalk, carriageway, and Carabinieri station facade without proper signage. The DPA ordered corrective measures and imposed €2,000 fine for violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(c), and 13.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration and negligent character as aggravating factors. Absence of precedents was mitigating, while lack of cooperation was aggravating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests for defensive investigations but the DPA found violations of information obligations and fairness principle due to lack of proper employee notification about workplace monitoring controls.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found Costampress S.p.A. violated GDPR by conducting employee computer monitoring without proper information disclosure. The company examined a former executive's laptop data through a digital forensics consultant without having established workplace monitoring policies. The DPA determined this violated transparency obligations and the fairness principle, while dismissing other complaint aspects regarding email, SIM card, and portability rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of violation (fairness principle) as aggravating, absence of precedents as mitigating, and the company's economic conditions based on 2020 revenues. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Melegnano and Martesana territorial social health company
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not claim a specific legal basis; the DPA found communication of health data to unauthorized third party violated Articles 5 and 9 due to lack of suitable legal basis for such disclosure.
a75_case_summary: A healthcare company erroneously delivered a medical report containing health data to an unauthorized patient. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f) and 9 due to inadequate security measures preventing unauthorized disclosure. The incident resulted from human error in manual report handling procedures. The company fully cooperated and implemented corrective measures including staff training and procedure updates.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included sensitive health data involved. Mitigating factors included negligent (not intentional) violation, full cooperation with authority, measures taken to mitigate damage, and notification of breach. Previous violations were considered neutral as they occurred after this incident.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis; the DPA found violations of Articles 12 and 17 of the Regulation due to failure to respond and deletion issues.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found that Arte del Vivere S.r.l. published personal data of 1897 individuals on a website without proper controls. When a data subject requested deletion of his data, the company failed to comply despite repeated requests. The DPA initiated an investigation and found violations of Articles 12 and 17 of the GDPR. The company took remedial actions only after DPA involvement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA did not systemically discuss Art 83(2) factors in the decision, but noted several mitigating factors including actions taken to mitigate damage (Art 83(2)(c) and cooperation with the supervisory authority (Art 83(2)(f).

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent was obtained but DPA found consent invalid as initial marketing call itself constituted unlawful processing; no valid legal basis existed for marketing activities using data collected online without proper consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on promotional activities and contrast to spam - 4 July 2013
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found real estate agency unlawfully processed personal data collected from websites for marketing purposes without valid consent. The agency made unwanted promotional calls and failed to respond to data subject rights requests. DPA issued corrective measures and €5,000 fine for violations of transparency, legal basis, and accountability principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: gross negligence, repeated contacts after opposition, inadequate cooperation. Mitigating: common data type, isolated complaint, limited turnover, no previous infringements. Neutral: not specifically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: Regional Agency for the Protection of the Environment of Abruzzo
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Agency claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(b) (contract) and 6(1)(c) (legal obligation). The DPA found Article 6(1)(b) invalid as public entities may only disclose data when permitted by law or regulation, and determined the publication was not justified under transparency laws as it concerned a draft conciliation report rather than final agreements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the processing of personal data, also contained in administrative deeds and documents, carried out for the purposes of advertising and transparency on the web by public entities and other obliged entities
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found the Regional Agency for Environmental Protection of Abruzzo violated GDPR by publishing a resolution containing an employee's personal data and information about a criminal proceeding on its website. The Agency claimed legal bases under contract and transparency obligations, but the DPA determined public entities may only disclose data when permitted by law, and the publication exceeded transparency requirements. The DPA imposed an €8,000 fine considering the sensitive nature of the data and duration of publication, while acknowledging mitigation factors including cooperation and prompt remediation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the sensitive nature of criminal data and extended publication period as aggravating factors. It considered the defendant's prompt remediation, full cooperation during investigation, and lack of previous violations as mitigating factors. The fine was reduced to €8,000 based on these considerations.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed violations occurred due to clerical errors. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (f), 9, and 32 due to unauthorized disclosure of health data to third parties without suitable legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA fined healthcare provider €10,000 for two separate incidents involving unauthorized disclosure of health data to third parties due to clerical errors in document handling. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (f), 9, and 32 for processing health data without suitable legal basis and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included prompt remedial actions, cooperation with authorities, and implementation of double-check procedures to prevent future errors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included the nature of health data and previous infringement. Mitigating factors included lack of intent, prompt mitigation actions, cooperation with authority, and implementation of corrective measures.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: National Institute for Accident Insurance at Work (INAIL)
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public interest tasks under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found the processing unlawful due to unauthorized data disclosures and absence of suitable regulatory requirement for such communications.
a75_case_summary: INAIL experienced three data breaches (2019-2020) where users could view others' accident/occupational disease files containing health data through its Virtual Helpdesk service. The DPA found violations of data protection principles due to unauthorized disclosures and inadequate security measures. The breaches were attributed to technical configuration issues and human error in deployment processes.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature of data (health), gravity of incidents, and inadequate security measures. Mitigating factors included prompt breach notification, cooperation with authority, measures to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, and the accidental nature of some incidents.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was justified for business needs and defense purposes, but the DPA found this interpretation would be elusive of GDPR legitimizing criteria, particularly as the processing referred to an ongoing dispute rather than abstract defense hypotheses.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines for e-mail and internet of 1 March 2007
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found Palumbo Superyacht violated GDPR by failing to provide information to an agent about email usage, improperly maintaining an active company email account after relationship termination, and denying access rights. The company blocked the agent's email access citing confidential information disclosure but kept the account active for business needs and potential defense purposes. The DPA found violations of principles of lawfulness, storage limitation, transparency obligations, and data subject access rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included grossly negligent conduct and inadequate cooperation. Mitigating factors included the isolated nature of the complaint, company's remedial measures, absence of previous infringements, and pandemic context. The sanction was set at €50,000 considering both aggravating and mitigating circumstances.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed legal basis under Art 6(1)(c) and Art 9(2)(b). DPA found no legal obligation existed to disclose pregnancy information to families, invalidating the claimed legal basis.
a75_case_summary: Educationest disclosed employee's pregnancy status to parents via email without consent. DPA found violation of privacy rights and data minimization principles. Company claimed legal obligation basis but DPA invalidated it. Fine imposed considering nature of violation and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; intentional/negligent character as aggravating; actions to mitigate damage as mitigating; no previous infringements as mitigating; categories of data affected as aggravating; pandemic context as mitigating factor.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Citynews S.p.a.;Il Gazzettino S.p.a.;Teleradio Diffusione Bassano S.r.l.
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that the publication of mugshot-like photographs portraying the complainant in detention violated journalistic data protection rules, as they were not essential for information purposes and damaged the dignity of the person, despite being provided by police authorities.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found three media companies violated data protection rules by publishing mugshot-like photographs of an arrested individual. The photos portrayed the complainant in detention positions and were deemed non-essential for journalistic purposes, damaging his dignity. The DPA issued reprimands and prohibited further dissemination of the photographs while allowing archival preservation for judicial purposes.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature of personal data (detention photos) as aggravating, while cooperation and remedial actions (removing photos) were mitigating factors. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under pandemic circumstances but DPA found no suitable legal basis for disclosing health data to third parties, violating Articles 5(1)(f) and 9.
a75_case_summary: Hospital sent newsletters to patients using CC instead of BCC, disclosing email addresses and health information. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f) and 9 as health data was communicated without legal basis. Fine imposed considering aggravating factors (health data, scale) and mitigating factors (cooperation, remedial measures, pandemic context).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: aggravating (nature/gravity, categories of data), mitigating (negligent not intentional, actions to mitigate damage, cooperation, Covid-19 context). No factors were neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed data was inserted by users with consent, but the DPA found no valid legal basis as the processing violated Italian telephone directory regulations and consent was not freely given due to pre-selected options.
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found Petta Fabio Giovanni violated GDPR by operating an unauthorized telephone directory website publishing personal data without legal basis. The site lacked proper identification of the controller, had ineffective deletion mechanisms, and violated multiple data subject rights. The DPA imposed a €50,000 fine and prohibited further processing for directory purposes.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors, finding 7 aggravating circumstances including seriousness, duration, negligence, lack of cooperation, and economic benefit. One mitigating factor was the defendant's status as a small entrepreneur. The fine was set at 0.25% of the statutory maximum.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed transfers were based on Standard Contractual Clauses with Google, but the DPA found these inadequate due to US surveillance laws preventing effective protection. The DPA determined the controller failed to verify adequacy of safeguards as required by accountability principle.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation No 1/2020 on measures supplementing the means of transfer to ensure compliance with the EU level of protection of personal data;WP 136 - Opinion No 4/2007 on the concept of personal data;EDPB and EDPS Joint Opinion 2/2021 on the European Commission Implementing Decision on standard contractual clauses for the transfer of personal data to third countries
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Caffeina Media S.r.l. unlawfully transferred personal data to Google LLC via Google Analytics without adequate safeguards. The transfers violated Chapter V requirements as US surveillance laws prevent effective protection despite Standard Contractual Clauses. The controller breached transparency obligations and accountability principle by failing to verify adequacy of transfers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. The nature/gravity was mitigated as no special categories were involved. The controller's negligence was mitigated due to Google's market dominance. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authorities, remedial measures taken, and absence of previous infringements.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria Integrata di Verona
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent for prospective data collection and Article 110 procedure for retrospective data from deceased/uncontactable patients. DPA found legal bases adequate for database creation but required additional specific consents for future research studies using the database.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Opinion 05/2014 on Anonymization techniques;Guidelines 5/2020 on consent pursuant to regulation (EU) 2016/679;Opinion 3/2019 on questions and answers on the interaction between the clinical trial regulation and the General Data Protection Regulation;Document on response to the request from the European Commission for clarifications on the consistent application of the GDPR, focusing on health research
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA issued opinion on prior consultation request from Verona University Hospital for DB Torax thoracic research database. DPA approved database creation but required additional specific consents for future research studies. DPA assessed data minimization, retention periods, anonymization techniques, and transparency measures. Conditions imposed included removing 25-year retention provision and implementing singularity removal procedures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Deutsche Bank failed to respond to a data subject access request within statutory timeframe. The bank claimed technical issues and that information was already known to complainant, but DPA rejected these arguments. Violations of Articles 12(3) and 15 GDPR were found, resulting in €20,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Nature/gravity was aggravating; cooperation, technical measures, and no previous violations were mitigating; violation affecting only one data subject was neutral. Fine was based on bank's economic conditions and 2020 revenues.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a7_defendant_name: Italian Federation of Sommeliers, Hoteliers and Restaurateurs
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for publishing disciplinary measures to inform members. The DPA found the processing unlawful because the publication concerned a non-final disciplinary measure that was later canceled, exceeding what members could reasonably expect and violating both consent and legitimate interest requirements.
a75_case_summary: FISAR published a non-final disciplinary exclusion measure against a member to all associates via cloud platform, violating internal regulations requiring definitive measures only. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (c) and 6(1) as the processing exceeded legitimate interest scope and reasonable expectations. A €5,000 fine was imposed considering the association's nonprofit status and cooperation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity was aggravating; corrective actions, no previous violations, and cooperation were mitigating; data categories were neutral. The nonprofit status was considered as an additional mitigating factor in determining the proportionate fine amount.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines no. 3/2019 of the European Data Protection Committee on the processing of personal data through video devices
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Immobiliare Riscostruzione Meloria s.r.l. violated GDPR Articles 5(1)(a) and 13 by operating CCTV without proper signage. The company installed cameras monitoring building entrance, lobby, courtyard and cellar access but only displayed a generic camera symbol without controller identity or processing purposes. DPA ordered installation of proper information signs and imposed €2,000 fine for transparency and information obligation violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to negligent conduct; lack of cooperation was aggravating; absence of previous infringements was mitigating; economic conditions were mitigating. The fine was set at €2,000 considering these factors and principles of effectiveness, proportionality and dissuasiveness.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on article 25 - Data protection by design and by default
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA found Integrated Water Service S.c.p.a. violated GDPR security requirements by using unencrypted HTTP protocol for its website's user area containing personal data and invoices. The company failed to promptly address security concerns raised twice by a complainant before the investigation. The DPA imposed a €15,000 fine considering the high number of affected users (13,000) but acknowledged the company's cooperation and remediation efforts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the high number of affected users (13,000) as aggravating, and the company's cooperation, prompt remediation, and lack of previous violations as mitigating factors. The nature of data processed was considered neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Company claimed it was not controller; DPA found it determined promotional purpose and was controller; consent basis invalid as no evidence of consent acquisition.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on promotional activities and contrast to spam of 4 July 2013;Opinion 7/2020 on the concept of data controller
a75_case_summary: Teatro Colosseo commissioned third party for promotional marketing; DPA found company was controller despite outsourcing; Violations included lack of consent for marketing, failure to respond to data subject rights, and inadequate accountability measures; Fine imposed was reduced due to mitigating factors including pandemic context and first offense.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; Aggravating: gross negligence and lack of response; Mitigating: low number of data subjects, common data, no previous infringements, no other complaints, pandemic situation, company financials; Neutral factors not discussed.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed emergency COVID-19 provisions as legal basis for removing privacy filters. The DPA found this invalid as the processing was not limited to COVID-19 patients or emergency services, and consent remained required for health dossier processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines regarding the health dossier - 4 June 2015
a75_case_summary: The Valle d'Aosta Local Health Authority removed privacy filters from its health dossier system during COVID-19, allowing all healthcare staff to access patient records regardless of treatment involvement or consent. A speech therapist accessed a colleague's health data out of "mere curiosity." The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(f), 9, 25, and 32 GDPR for processing health data without proper legal basis and security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional character, categories of data affected, and inadequate technical measures. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage and restoration of pre-pandemic measures. Cooperation was neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: Vodafone claimed consent was obtained through an inbound call from the data subject, but the DPA found this claim contradicted by evidence and insufficient to prove valid consent under Article 6(1)(a). The DPA determined Vodafone failed to demonstrate proper consent acquisition for marketing purposes.
a75_case_summary: Vodafone contacted an 85-year-old complainant through telemarketing without valid consent. The DPA found Vodafone's claim of prior consent contradicted by evidence and determined the consent formula was incomprehensible and undifferentiated. Violations included lack of proper information, invalid consent, and unfair processing practices. A €500,000 fine was imposed considering aggravating and mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: seriousness of violations (aggravating), previous infringements (aggravating), actions to mitigate damage (mitigating), and general socio-economic context (mitigating). The fine was set at €500,000 based on these considerations.

a2_authority_name: THE GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: FCA Italy failed to respond to an employee's formal access request sent via lawyers in January 2021, claiming they could handle it through personal meetings per established practice. The DPA found this violated Articles 12 and 15 as the company should have responded in writing within statutory timelines. The violation lasted approximately seven months until the company finally provided documentation during the procedure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violation, negligent character, previous relevant violations, and insufficient technical measures. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage, and that the violation concerned only one complainant in an isolated case.

a2_authority_name: THE GUARANTOR FOR THE PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A volunteer member resigned and requested data deletion from Codess Sociale cooperative. The company failed to respond to the erasure request within the required timeframe and only provided reasons after the Authority's intervention. The DPA found violations of Article 12 in relation to Article 17 GDPR for failure to respond to data subject rights requests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to violation concerning data subject rights and long duration. Absence of previous violations, cooperation during proceedings, and social nature of activity were mitigating factors. Economic conditions based on 2021 revenues were considered.

a2_authority_name: Guarantor for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis for Green Pass verification; DPA found legal basis must be specific sector regulations for public health purposes; Consent invalid as basis for health data processing requiring higher legal standard.
a75_case_summary: Policlinico Casilino required Green Pass verification for clinic access despite national regulations exempting healthcare services. DPA found processing unlawful as it lacked proper legal basis under sector-specific public health regulations. Controller incorrectly relied on consent rather than required higher legal standard for health data. Processing violated principles of lawfulness and purpose limitation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/gravity, data categories, previous infringements. Mitigating: cooperation, remedial actions, good faith. Neutral: manner infringement became known. Fine set at €30,000 considering all factors.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed contract and legitimate interest as legal bases for various processing activities. The DPA found these bases invalid for marketing, profiling, and audio recording/sharing purposes, stating they required consent instead.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 2/2019 on the processing of personal data pursuant to article 6, paragraph 1, letter b), of the general regulation on data protection in the context of the provision of online services to data subjects;Guidelines on the automated decision-making process relating to individuals and on profiling for the purposes of regulation 2016/679;Opinion 6/2014 on the concept of legitimate interest of the [owner] of the treatment pursuant to article 7 of directive 95/46/EC
a75_case_summary: The Italian DPA found Alpha Exploration Co. Inc. (Clubhouse) violated GDPR principles and transparency obligations. The case involved improper legal bases for marketing, profiling, and audio processing activities. The DPA imposed corrective measures and a €2 million fine for multiple violations including inadequate information provision and failure to conduct a DPIA.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included seriousness, duration, number of data subjects, and negligent character. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authorities and measures to mitigate damage. The economic capacity of the company was considered as an additional factor.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The Foundation claimed transparency obligations required publication; DPA found no suitable legal basis under Article 6(1) for publishing health data and information revealing disciplinary procedures.
a75_case_summary: Fondazione Teatro Regio published employee health data and disciplinary information on its website under transparency obligations. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (c), 6(1), and Italian Code Article 2-septies(8) for unlawful processing without proper legal basis. Fine imposed considered nature of violation, corrective actions taken, and cooperation with authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating: nature/gravity of violation and categories of data affected. Mitigating: culpable nature was negligent error, actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, cooperation with authority, and other mitigating circumstances including isolated case and prompt correction.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for biometric data processing. The DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship and lack of proper authorization under Article 9(2)(b) requiring Union or Member State law with appropriate safeguards.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent pursuant to EU Regulation 2016/679 - WP 259;Opinion 2/2017 on the processing of data on site of work, WP 249
a75_case_summary: Sportitalia implemented biometric fingerprint system for employee attendance monitoring without proper legal basis. The Italian DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 9, 13, and 30(1)(c) for unlawful biometric processing, inadequate information, and incomplete processing register. The company ceased processing and cooperated, receiving €20,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violation and categories of data affected. Mitigating factors included negligent character, cooperation with authority, absence of previous violations, and economic difficulties. The manner infringement became known was neutral.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not discuss specific legal bases as the case focused on accuracy, storage limitation, and accountability violations rather than legal basis validity.
a75_case_summary: Areti S.p.A., an electricity distributor, processed inaccurate customer data in its compensation system from 2016-2022, wrongly classifying 16,743 customers as defaulters. The DPA found violations of accuracy, storage limitation, and accountability principles, plus inadequate response to data subject rights. A €1 million fine was imposed considering the scale, duration, and systemic nature of the violations, though mitigation was given for cooperation and remedial actions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of violation, inadequate technical measures, and sensitive nature of financial reliability data. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, no previous violations, and the complex regulatory context. The economic conditions of the defendant were considered in fine calculation.

a2_authority_name: Garante per la protezione dei dati personali
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: Amazon Italia Logistica failed to adequately respond to an employee's access request regarding professional certificates. The DPA found violations of Articles 12 and 15 GDPR due to failure to respond promptly and provide required information. The company's defense citing request format and internal coordination issues was rejected based on EDPB guidelines.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, while intentional/negligent character, mitigation actions, cooperation, and previous infringements were mitigating. Categories of data were neutral. Other factors like economic conditions and similar cases were considered.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Meta claimed processing was based on public interest/legitimate interests; DPA found no valid legal basis as Meta is a private company pursuing commercial objectives unrelated to public interest; consent and contract bases were also invalidated.
a75_case_summary: Italian DPA initiated urgency procedure against Meta's election-related data processing during Italian general elections. Found prima facie violations of legal basis requirements (Articles 6/9), data minimization (Article 5(1)(c)), and storage limitation (Article 5(1)(e)). Issued 3-month warning under Article 58(2)(a) due to lack of substantive feedback from lead authority (Irish DPC).
