The case will continue through normal Article 60 cooperation procedure with Dutch DPA as lead authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed transfers were based on Article 46 protective measures; the DPA found these measures insufficient given new Russian legislation granting security services broad access rights; the DPA determined transfers would violate GDPR Chapter V principles and fundamental rights protections.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA issued urgent temporary ban on Yango taxi app data transfers to Russia due to new legislation granting Russian security services broad access to passenger data. The DPA found Article 46 protective measures insufficient given the risk of unauthorized access. The ban takes effect September 1, 2023 and lasts three months under Article 66 urgent procedure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, noting the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to serious risks to fundamental rights. Other aggravating factors included the new Russian legislation creating unrestricted access. Most Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for direct marketing in lottery participation. The DPA found consent valid and voluntary under Article 4(11) despite being conditional, noting participation was voluntary and not giving consent caused no negative consequences. The DPA also found withdrawal mechanisms compliant with Article 7(3).
a75_case_summary: The Finnish DPA investigated a complaint about a lottery requiring consent for direct marketing as participation condition. The DPA found the consent voluntary under Article 4(11) despite conditionality, noting lottery participation was optional and refusal caused no harm. The DPA also found withdrawal mechanisms compliant with Article 7(3) and issued no sanctions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for identification in decisions, enforcement of payments, and insurance requirements. The DPA found these justifications invalid as invoices are not decisions, enforcement doesn't require SSN on invoices, and insurance companies don't require SSN-marked invoices.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered a municipal healthcare provider to cease printing social security numbers on patient invoices. The controller claimed SSNs were necessary for identification, enforcement, and insurance purposes. The DPA rejected all arguments, finding the practice violated data minimization and security principles under GDPR and national data protection law.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA ordered credit registry to remove default entries from applicant's credit information. The DPA found that a bankruptcy application that was withdrawn and never became final could not serve as extension basis for maintaining default entries under Credit Information Act. The DPA also found that default entries based on unilateral judgments that were later set aside should be removed as they no longer accurately reflected the applicant's creditworthiness.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller did not properly implement the data subject's right of access under Article 15 and failed to provide adequate information about its role as controller. The DPA found violations of transparency obligations and data subject rights facilitation requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: A medical clinic failed to properly implement a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR. The DPA found systematic violations including failure to facilitate data subject rights, inadequate transparency information, and poor cooperation with the supervisory authority. The clinic processed health data but lacked proper procedures for rights implementation and information provision. A €5,000 fine was imposed due to the serious and systematic nature of the violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/duration of violation, negligent character, failure to mitigate damage, inadequate technical measures, poor cooperation, and processing of special category health data. No mitigating factors were identified. The violation was considered serious and systematic.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A cleaning company used WhatsApp to transmit customer personal data including names, addresses, telephone numbers, door codes and alarm system codes to employees' personal phones. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 24, 25 and 32 GDPR due to inadequate security measures and failure to implement built-in data protection. The controller was issued a reprimand and ordered to bring processing into compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal obligation under Article 17(3)(b) for data retention; DPA found this valid due to statutory healthcare record retention requirements; Controller was not required to delete data but failed to properly respond to deletion requests.
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found optician shop violated GDPR by continuing direct marketing after data subject's objection and failing to properly respond to deletion requests. Controller claimed legal obligation to retain health data under national law, which DPA validated. DPA issued reprimand for violations of Articles 12(4), 21(2), and 25(2) but no fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA rejected a parent's request to exercise GDPR rights on behalf of minor child regarding medical data. The parent had court-confirmed information access rights but was not the guardian. DPA determined information access rights under national law do not extend to exercising GDPR correction/deletion rights. No order issued as applicant lacked standing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A psychotherapist failed to respond to a patient's data access requests under Article 15 GDPR for nearly three years despite multiple requests and DPA guidance. The DPA found violations of Article 12(3) and (4) GDPR regarding timely response to data subject requests. The controller claimed exceptional circumstances but the DPA found intentional neglect of GDPR obligations, particularly concerning sensitive health data processing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: nature/duration of violation (3-year delay), intentional character, failure to mitigate damage, inadequate technical measures, lack of cooperation with DPA, and sensitive health data involved. Neutral factors included: no previous infringements and no financial benefit obtained.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on consent as stated in their privacy policy. The DPA found Article 20 applies to email data as it involves data consciously provided by the subject and generated from their activities, and processing is automated.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP29 Guidelines on the right to data portability
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found email service provider violated Article 20 by only allowing manual export of emails one-by-one for free users while charging for bulk export tools. The DPA determined this effectively hindered data portability and made full exercise of the right chargeable, violating Article 12(5). A reprimand was issued under Article 58(2)(b).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b);DPA found processing for customer account creation was not objectively necessary for online purchase contract;DPA stated contract basis should be interpreted narrowly and processing was typically for business benefit
a75_case_summary: Finnish DPA found Verkkokauppa.com violated storage limitation principle by requiring customer registration for single online purchases;Controller stored personal data indefinitely unless data subject requested deletion;DPA held this transferred data protection responsibility to data subjects and violated Articles 5(1)(e) and 25(2);Controller was ordered to define proper retention periods and fined €856,000
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors;Nature and duration of violation were aggravating (deliberate practice since 2018 affecting millions);Intentional character was aggravating (controller consciously implemented non-compliant procedure);Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (planned inactive account deletion mechanism)

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was for educational purposes but the DPA found personal data was used to promote third-party sports services without legal basis, violating purpose limitation and lawfulness principles.
a75_case_summary: A college teacher used the college's information system to send marketing emails promoting third-party sports courses to students. The DPA found this violated Article 5 principles as the processing was unrelated to college operations and lacked legal basis. The city as controller received a reprimand for failing to ensure proper data handling by staff.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Finnish Tax Administration required data subject to submit signed paper form for access request and refused to deliver data to agent. DPA found violations of Article 12(2) for failing to facilitate data subject rights. Ordered compliance with GDPR and processing of original request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but the DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 regarding security of processing health data transmitted to third-party monitoring services.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Guidelines on the application and imposition of administrative fines under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: University Pharmacy transmitted health data (medicine browsing/purchase information) to third-party monitoring services (Google, Meta, New Relic) without adequate security measures. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5(1)(f) and 32 GDPR. The infringement lasted approximately four years during GDPR application period and affected a large number of data subjects. The penalty was imposed due to the serious nature of processing sensitive health data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, technical/organizational measures, and categories of personal data affected. Mitigating factor was that controller's revenues support education/research. Neutral factors included actions to mitigate damage and cooperation with authority.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Data subject requested access to call recording and materials related to customer satisfaction survey. Controller initially provided transcription instead of electronic recording, then provided both after repeated request. Deputy DPA found controller complied with Articles 12(1) and 15(3) by assessing appropriate delivery format and providing both transcription and electronic recording. No violations found, no corrective measures issued.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA overturned initial decision not to investigate complaint about Storybook OÜ processing personal data from commercial register to create personal profiles. DPA acknowledged ongoing supervision of information portals including Storybook but found complainant had right to individual complaint procedure. Decision orders processing of complainant's specific case.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a7_defendant_name: Center of Registers and Information Systems
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Data Protection Inspectorate dismissed a challenge regarding allegedly inaccurate criminal record data. The Inspectorate found that the criminal record entry was lawful as it was based on a valid court judgment that remained in force despite multiple appeals. The DPA concluded the data processing had legal basis under national criminal register legislation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes under national law §4 of Personal Data Protection Act, but the DPA found that GDPR applies to processing beyond what was published and that the controller breached its obligation to respond to the data subject's access request.
a75_case_summary: Viimsi Uudised OÜ, a media company, failed to respond to a data subject's access request under Article 15 GDPR regarding personal data collected for a "Viimsi Brake 2020" survey. The DPA found the controller breached its obligation to respond within one month and issued a precept ordering compliance with the access request while allowing redaction of third-party information. The controller incorrectly argued that a previous court ruling prevented the DPA's supervision.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis. The DPA found that after termination of employment, there was no legal basis for keeping the email addresses open, as the original legal basis (employment contract) no longer applied.
a75_case_summary: The Estonian DPA issued an injunction against Retent AS for failing to delete former employee email addresses after employment termination. The DPA found no legal basis for keeping the addresses open after the employment contract ended. The company failed to respond to multiple requests from both the data subject and the DPA.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed no legal basis; DPA found no valid consent under Article 6(1)(a) and no legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f); Disclosure of debt data without legal grounds violated GDPR principles.
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPA ordered individual Facebook group administrator to cease illegal disclosure of debtors' personal data. Controller failed to demonstrate valid legal basis under Article 6(1)(a) consent or 6(1)(f) legitimate interest. DPA issued injunction to terminate processing and delete Facebook group containing unlawfully published personal data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA cited nature/gravity of infringement (illegal public disclosure) and categories of data affected as aggravating factors; failure to comply with prior proposal also considered aggravating; no systematic Article 83(2) discussion.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent and contractual basis for processing, but the DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 9 for processing special category health data. The DPA determined that displaying prescription data based solely on personal identification codes without verification of legal representation rights violated GDPR requirements.
a75_case_summary: The Estonian DPA discovered that e-pharmacies allowed anyone with ID card login to access others' prescription data by entering personal identification codes. The DPA issued an urgent injunction requiring immediate suspension of this processing due to high risk to data subjects' sensitive health information. The DPA found violations of data protection principles including lawfulness, data minimization, and security requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, noting the nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, categories of personal data affected as aggravating, and technical/organizational measures as aggravating. The decision focused on the high risk to data subjects rather than systematic Article 83(2) analysis.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Estonian DPI investigated Bolt Operations OÜ regarding a data subject's right to rectification of phone number data. Bolt failed to respond to rectification requests in due time and had technical limitations preventing phone number changes. The DPI issued proposals for system changes and response improvements, which Bolt implemented after delays. The DPI found violations of GDPR articles regarding rectification rights, response timelines, and security measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: JobTeam A/S deleted personal data after receiving an access request but before responding, violating GDPR principles. The Danish Data Inspectorate reported the company to police and recommended a DKK 50,000 fine. The authority emphasized fines must be effective, dissuasive, and proportionate to the infringement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis. The DPA found this invalid because continuous CPR subscriptions were not necessary when single inquiries could suffice for identification needs in handling citizen requests.
a75_case_summary: The City of Copenhagen maintained continuous CPR subscriptions for former residents without current need. A citizen complaint revealed automatic resubscription upon inquiry. The DPA found Article 6(1)(e) invalid as single inquiries suffice for identification needs, violating data minimization principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed medical consultant assessments were internal documents exempt from access rights under business secrets and private interests. The DPA found these assessments constitute personal data and exceptions to access rights are very narrow, requiring concrete assessment rather than general refusal.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Article 29 Working Party Opinion No 4/2007 on the concept of personal data (WP136)
a75_case_summary: A pension company refused access to medical consultant assessments claiming they were internal documents exempt from access rights. The Danish DPA found medical assessments constitute personal data and exceptions to access rights are very narrow, requiring concrete assessment rather than general refusal. The DPA issued serious criticism and an order to conduct a concrete assessment of whether access should be granted.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: TDC claimed processing based on legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) for accounting data and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for marketing profiling. DPA found legal obligation valid for accounting but storage period exceeded legal requirements. DPA found legitimate interests valid for marketing profiling until objection.
a75_case_summary: DPA addressed multiple complaints against TDC Group companies regarding data processing practices. Found TDC A/S violated Article 15 by delayed response to access request. Found Dansk Kabel TV A/S violated Article 6(1) and Article 5(1)(e) by retaining accounting data beyond legal requirements. Found no violations for Nuuday A/S's marketing profiling or disclosure practices.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA reprimanded Reto Moto ApS for failing to provide copies of direct in-game chat messages under Article 15(3). The DPA found Reto Moto was entitled to withhold other chat messages under Article 15(4) due to language/jargon complexities and anti-cheat information under Danish Data Protection Act section 22(1) due to trade secrets. The case involved a complaint about incomplete response to an access request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing under Article 6(1)(c) and (e) and Danish Data Protection Act section 11(1). The DPA found processing was conducted on a basis other than consent, which was appropriate for the public task of recovering claims.
a75_case_summary: The Labor Market Holiday Fund failed to provide complete transparency information within required timeframes and requested invalid consent. The DPA found violations of Articles 12(1), 14, and 5(1)(a) for providing information piecemeal over months rather than in a single concise communication, and for requesting consent when processing was already based on legal obligation/public task.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent as legal basis but DPA found contract and legal obligation were more appropriate bases. DPA criticized using consent when other bases were clearly more suitable, as consent gives data subjects control expectation that shouldn't apply to necessary contractual/legal processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP259 rev. 01 Guidelines on Consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: DPA found Rejsekort improperly used consent as legal basis for processing travel card data when contract and legal obligation bases were more appropriate. DPA issued serious criticism and ordered deletion of travel data and agreement information not required by Accounting Act. Controller must reassess processing bases for all consent-based processing and submit written statement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis. DPA found processing necessary for municipality's exercise of authority and valid under Article 6(1)(e). Reasoning emphasized search function supports compliance with general duty of guidance to citizens.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA ruled on complaint about municipality's website search function suggesting complainant's name. Municipality claimed processing under Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for providing citizen guidance. DPA found processing lawful and necessary for municipality's exercise of authority, complying with data minimization principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned supervision of law firm's email security practices. Found firm uses end-to-end encryption with S/MIME certificates and forced TLS 1.2 for transmitting confidential/sensitive data. Firm demonstrated adequate risk assessment and no known unencrypted transmissions since January 2019.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned audit of law firm office community focusing on email encryption security. Found violations of Article 32 security requirements and Article 5(2) accountability principle for failing to implement TLS encryption procedures and conduct proper risk assessment for transmitting confidential/sensitive personal data to clients. Office community implemented corrective procedures post-audit but received formal reprimand for prior non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered inadequate security measures as aggravating and post-audit remedial actions as mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted beyond these factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that SIF Gruppen failed to provide information about the legal basis for processing personal data in connection with GPS monitoring, which violated transparency requirements.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted written inspection of SIF Gruppen regarding employee monitoring practices. Found deficient information provision for GPS monitoring (missing legal basis, data subject rights, complaint information) and TV surveillance (lack of transparency about control purposes). Issued serious criticism and orders to comply with Articles 5(1)(a), 13 and 14.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA conducted planned audit of Payment Denmark's compliance with data subject rights. Found violations of Articles 15 and 12(2) regarding access requests and automated decision information. Authority failed to provide information about automated decisions in 5 cases and missed response deadlines in 4 cases.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The Conservative People's Party claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests. The DPA found this valid, noting the processing was necessary for the party's legitimate interest in informing potential voters, involved publicly available name/address data, and did not interfere with data subjects' rights.
a74_guidelines_referenced: WP 260 rev. 01 guidelines for transparency in accordance with Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA found the Conservative People's Party violated Article 14 transparency obligations by failing to provide required information when collecting voter data from third parties. The party sent targeted campaign letters using names/addresses obtained from Geomatic based on segmentation of statistical and public data. While the DPA found legitimate interests basis valid under Article 6(1)(f), it rejected the party's claim that Danish practice exempted them from disclosure duties.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: BEC, a data processor for Danish banks, inadvertently disclosed protected address information for over 20,000 persons during automated payment transfers between banks from May 2018 to August 2019. The error resulted from system flaws including improper data conversion, reset address protection markers, and lack of address protection checks for special addresses. The DPA found breaches of Article 5(1)(f) and Article 32(1) due to inadequate security measures and failure to detect the longstanding system errors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: aggravating factors included the large number of affected customers, sensitive nature of protected addresses, and duration of errors since 2015. Mitigating factors included conflicting regulatory requirements and BEC's prompt remediation actions after discovery. The DPA issued serious criticism but no fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found consent invalid as not specific, informed, or voluntary. DPA emphasized lack of granularity for multiple purposes and insufficient information about marketing use and storage period.
a75_case_summary: Epic Booking processed nearly 500,000 photos of children/young people on Facebook without valid consent. DPA found consent invalid due to lack of specificity and information about purposes/storage. Violated storage limitation principle by indefinite retention. Ordered deletion of existing photos and 60-day maximum retention for future photos.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to extensive processing over many years. Categories of personal data was aggravating due to children's special protection. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of public task under Article 6(1)(e). DPA found this valid as Visitdenmark is a public authority and processing was necessary for carrying out tasks under public authority.
a75_case_summary: Visitdenmark, a public authority, processed personal data to send letters via Digital Post informing cottage owners about new tax rules. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for public task performance. However, Visitdenmark failed to adequately comply with Article 14 disclosure obligations when collecting data from BBR register, warranting criticism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: A citizen complained that Velliv insurance company did not provide full access to personal data processed about him. The DPA found Velliv properly withheld internal working documents containing legal assessments and correspondence with lawyers under Danish Data Protection Act §22. The DPA determined Velliv complied with Article 15 as personal data in withheld materials had already been provided and legal assessments didn't contain personal data about the complainant.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found insurance company violated Article 15 right of access by refusing to provide surveillance material (photos, videos, observation reports) collected during monitoring of complainant. Company claimed exemption under Danish Data Protection Act section 22 citing protection of business interests and police investigation, but DPA found no imminent danger of significant damage to justify withholding objective surveillance data. DPA issued serious criticism reprimand but no fine as material was eventually provided.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Cryos International ApS refused to provide a sperm donor with information about the number of children conceived using his donations, claiming this wasn't personal data about him and would violate others' rights. The Danish DPA found that information about the number of donor children constitutes personal data about the donor and must be disclosed under Article 15. The DPA issued criticism and an order requiring Cryos to provide this information by December 7, 2021.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA ruled that father's use of Orienteringsret.dk website for requesting child information fell under household exemption (Article 2(2)(c)). The website itself was subject to GDPR as it provided means for processing personal data. DPA conducted security assessment but found no grounds to establish violation of Article 32 security requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(d) and (e) as legal bases. DPA found Article 6(1)(e) invalid for general recording practice as it was not necessary for public task performance. DPA also found Article 6(1)(d) invalid as vital interests protection should only apply exceptionally.
a75_case_summary: Danish Business Authority recorded all incoming calls to customer center since 2018 for police documentation and training purposes. DPA found general recording practice violated data minimization principle and could not be justified under Article 6(1)(e) public task basis. DPA issued serious criticism and ordered compliance within 4 weeks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed processing was necessary for performance of public task under Article 6(1)(e) and Danish Statistics Act. DPA found this legal basis valid as Statistics Denmark has authority to collect statistical information and processing was necessary for this task.
a75_case_summary: Statistics Denmark failed to properly register complainant on internal opt-out list despite multiple requests, resulting in continued survey contacts. DPA found legal basis valid under Article 6(1)(e) for public task but criticized accuracy violation under Article 5(1)(d). No deletion obligation under Article 17(3)(b) as processing necessary for statistical purposes. Internal procedures initiated to prevent future errors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA noted Statistics Denmark initiated internal procedures to ensure proper registration of opt-outs as mitigating factor. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed in the decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent (Art 6(1)(a)) for competition data processing and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for questionnaire data sharing. DPA found consent valid for competition data but invalidated legitimate interests basis for questionnaire data sharing, requiring consent due to detailed nature of information.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Article 29-Group Opinion 6/2014 on the legitimate interests of the controller as referred to in Article 7 of Directive 95/46/EC
a75_case_summary: DPA investigated SmartResponse's processing of personal data through internet competitions and questionnaires. Found consent valid for competition data collection but invalidated legitimate interests basis for sharing detailed questionnaire data. Issued serious criticism for unnecessary no-thanks list processing and 5-year storage period violating data minimization and storage limitation principles. Ordered deletion of no-thanks list data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for processing website visitor data for statistical purposes. DPA found processing valid under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for municipality's exercise of authority to optimize website efficiency and user-friendliness for citizens.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA initiated own-motion investigation into Næstved Municipality's processing of website visitor data via cookies. Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis for statistical processing to optimize website user experience. DPA found violation of Article 5(1)(a) due to misleading text suggesting marketing purposes, but validated processing under Article 6(1)(e) for statistical purposes as part of municipal authority exercise.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: DBU and Divisionsforeningen refused access to CCTV footage from football stadium citing public safety concerns. DPA found Article 5(1)(a) breached due to conflicting information about data responsibility but upheld refusal of access under Danish Data Protection Act section 22 exemptions for public security. DPA recommended future specific assessments of access requests.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint about Trustpilot's response to access request regarding invitation emails sent on behalf of Asus Online Shop. Trustpilot claimed processor status for invitation emails but controller status for website usage. DPA investigated but decision outcome not specified in provided text.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for investigating workplace culture and potential abusive acts. The DPA found this legal basis valid for collecting general personal data but invalid for processing special category data without proper safeguards under Article 9.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Article 29 Working Party Guidelines for transparency under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: TV2 and law firm Norrbom Vinding conducted a workplace investigation into historical abusive acts and culture issues. The DPA found legitimate interests valid for general data collection under Article 6(1)(f) but criticized the broad collection of special category data without proper Article 9 safeguards. The DPA also found transparency violations under Articles 12-14 and issued serious criticism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. The nature/gravity of the infringement was aggravating due to sensitive data processing. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to failure to implement proper safeguards. Categories of personal data affected was aggravating due to special category data.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent was valid under Article 6(1)(a); DPA found consent not voluntary for statistical purposes processing; DPA required demonstration that statistical processing is necessary part of paid alternative or separate consent mechanism.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA examined GulogGratis' cookie wall implementation offering choice between consent or payment. Found consent generally valid when payment alternative is reasonable and provides equivalent service. However, controller failed to demonstrate statistical processing was necessary part of paid alternative, violating accountability principle and consent requirements. Issued order to demonstrate necessity or implement separate consent for statistical purposes.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found controllers not obligated to search/review over 1 million documents for complainant's access request. Documents related to complainant's board member role and ongoing litigation. DPA determined information appeared accessory to business function and request was excessive under Article 12(5)(b).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed Article 6(1)(d) vital interests; DPA found Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interests was correct basis; DPA upheld controller's assessment that processing was necessary to prevent fraud and maintain platform blocking
a75_case_summary: DPA rejected complaint about right to erasure; DBA retained user data to block complainant from platform due to multiple fraud complaints; DPA found legitimate interests basis valid under Article 6(1)(f); Storage limitation principle not breached as data automatically deleted after 24 months inactivity
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: TeeShoppen failed to delete complainant's personal data for marketing purposes despite previous 2020 complaint and assurance of deletion. DPA found violation of Article 17(1)(c) right to erasure when objecting to marketing. DPA issued serious criticism and order to delete data by August 23, 2022, which company complied with on same day.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found consent invalid due to lack of voluntariness as the service offered against consent was not equivalent to paid alternative
a74_guidelines_referenced: European Data Protection Board, Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation 2016/679, v. 1.1
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA found Jysk Fynske Medier's cookie wall implementation invalid as consent was not voluntary. The company offered different content levels for consent vs payment, failing to provide equivalent alternatives. DPA issued order to ensure consent meets GDPR requirements for voluntariness.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent invalid due to unequal employer-employee relationship. DPA found legitimate interest basis valid under Article 6(1)(f) as security approval was necessary for employment tasks.
a75_case_summary: Former security guard complained that Securitas A/S disclosed personal data to intelligence services without consent for security clearance. DPA found consent invalid due to employer-employee power imbalance but upheld processing under Article 6(1)(f) legitimate interest basis. Security approval was necessary for employment tasks and disclosure of social security number was justified for unique identification.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest basis under Article 6(1)(f) to avoid rumors. The DPA found this invalid because the data subject's interests outweighed this interest, as the information went beyond what was necessary.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA criticized an employer for informing entire workplace about employee dismissal due to cooperation difficulties. Employer claimed legitimate interest to prevent rumors. DPA found data subject's interests outweighed employer's interest as information went beyond what was necessary for informing about resignation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a7_defendant_name: National Board of Health and Welfare
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 6(1)(e) and for legal claims under Article 9(2)(f). The DPA found some disclosures were necessary but others exceeded what was required for the tortfeasor to relate to the recourse claim.
a75_case_summary: The Danish Civil Agency disclosed excessive personal data about a crime victim to the tortfeasor during recourse proceedings. While some disclosure was necessary to establish legal claims, the agency shared unnecessary information including details about family members, school changes, and psychological treatments. The DPA found violations of data minimization principles and issued serious criticism along with orders to update internal guidelines.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed nature/gravity as aggravating due to sensitive data and police protection orders. Technical measures were aggravating as insufficient redaction occurred. Cooperation was mitigating as the agency acknowledged errors and updated guidelines. Damage mitigation was mitigating through subsequent procedural improvements.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(e) (public task). The DPA found the processing valid under this basis, noting both agencies have authority under national laws (Tax Control Act and Debt Recovery Act) to perform their official duties including tax assessment and debt recovery.
a75_case_summary: A citizen complained that the Tax Agency shared inheritance information with the Debt Agency within the Tax Administration. The DPA found the sharing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as both agencies perform public tasks related to state proceeds. The DPA determined the sharing did not violate purpose limitation as there was significant connection between tax assessment and debt recovery tasks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent (Art 6(1)(a)) for preferences/statistics/marketing and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for functional purposes. DPA found consent invalid due to lack of informed consent and color nudging, but found legitimate interests valid for functional cookie processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: DPA found JP/Politikens Hus's cookie consent solution violated GDPR consent requirements. The "Accept all" option failed to inform users about preference processing purpose, and color scheme (green=accept, red=reject) constituted problematic nudging. DPA expressed serious criticism but only addressed the previous consent solution as defendant had already changed it.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA did not assess legal bases as no violation was found; the case focused on security measures and balancing of interests in an emergency situation.
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA investigated Joannahuset crisis center for requesting social security number via SMS. The DPA found no violation as the specific emergency situation justified balancing data protection against the young person's immediate safety needs. The DPA acknowledged that while SMS transmission poses security risks, considerations for the vulnerable youth's welfare outweighed data protection concerns in this exceptional case.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on public task authority under Section 222 of the Health Act. The DPA did not invalidate this legal basis but focused on transparency obligations under Article 14.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency under Regulation 2016/679 (wp260rev.01);Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25, Data protection by design and data protection by default
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA investigated SSI's compliance with Article 14 information obligations regarding blood sample analysis and biobank storage. SSI argued notification would require disproportionate effort due to system limitations and costs. The DPA found SSI cannot invoke Article 14(5)(b) exception as difficulties were not caused by indirect data collection but by inadequate system setup. SSI was ordered to explain how it will fulfill Article 14 obligations within 3 months.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found insufficient allocation of roles and responsibilities between Boligportal and Meta Ireland as joint controllers, particularly regarding compliance with Article 26 GDPR for demonstrating lawful processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 07/2020 on controllers and processors
a75_case_summary: BoligPortal was reprimanded for failing to demonstrate compliance with GDPR regarding joint controllership with Meta Ireland for processing website visitor data through Facebook Business Tools. The DPA found insufficient allocation of responsibilities under Article 26 GDPR and ordered compliance. The decision did not rule on actual data transfers to the US due to factual disagreements between parties.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal authority but the DPA focused exclusively on data minimization principle violation without assessing legal basis validity.
a75_case_summary: The Danish Agency for Digitalisation processed personal data of all 3.96 million Danish driving license holders for its digital driving license app, though only 1.7 million had joined. The DPA found this violated Article 5(1)(c) data minimization principle as processing extended to 2.26 million non-users without necessity. The DPA issued serious criticism and banned processing of non-users' data, requiring cessation within 4 weeks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the nature and gravity of the infringement aggravating due to extensive processing of personal data without necessity. Technical limitations cited by the agency were deemed insufficient justification. Categories of personal data affected included sensitive data, further aggravating the violation. Other Article 83(2) factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA issued serious criticism to Clemens Bar ApS for deleting CCTV footage after refusing data subject's access request. The nightclub refused access citing security concerns and potential infringement of others' rights. DPA found deletion violated Article 5(1)(a) by depriving complainant of ability to verify rights through DPA or courts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA ruled on two complaints regarding the Danish Development and Simplification Agency's refusal to disclose the identity of an unintended recipient of personal data. The DPA found that unintended recipients fall within the broad definition of "recipient" under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR and that the auditor's name was not confidential under tax confidentiality rules. The DPA ordered the agency to provide information about the auditor but upheld the refusal regarding the client's identity.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found Article 6(1)(e) and Article 9(2)(g) could serve as legal bases but require supplementary national legal basis. Development was valid under existing Services Act provisions, but operation required clearer legal basis due to intrusive nature of AI processing.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA assessed Copenhagen Municipality's authority to develop and operate an AI solution predicting citizens' need for rehabilitation. While development was authorized under existing Services Act provisions, operation required clearer legal basis due to intrusive AI processing of sensitive health data affecting vulnerable groups. The DPA emphasized AI's fundamentally different nature from traditional case processing necessitating greater legal clarity.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA inspected 6 municipalities' processing security in AULA education system. Found deficiencies in risk assessments and impact analyses regarding processing of children's sensitive data. Issued orders for impact analyses and expressed criticism/serious criticism regarding inadequate security measures and documentation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to high risks to children's data. Lack of technical/organizational measures was aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating. Other factors not systematically discussed under Art 83(2).

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA criticized the Ministry of Immigration and Integration for failing to conduct ongoing checks on automatic deletion practices in the national visa information system, violating accountability principles under GDPR Article 5(2). The ministry also failed to immediately delete information when visa applicants obtained EU citizenship before deletion deadlines, violating VIS Regulation Article 25(1). Additionally, the ministry failed to notify responsible Member States when applicants obtained Danish citizenship, violating VIS Regulation Article 25(2).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on user consent through Tink API, but the DPA found this resulted in processing beyond what was necessary for the purpose. The DPA determined that controllers cannot base processing on scenarios where they are aware more data than necessary will be processed.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA investigated Dansk Retursystem's Pant app for mortgage payments which integrated Tink's API to obtain bank account information. The DPA found the app processed excessive personal data beyond what was necessary for the payment purpose, including balances, loans, transaction history and identity information. The DPA held Dansk Retursystem responsible as controller for violating data minimization and lawfulness principles, regardless of using third-party APIs. The company was ordered to bring processing into compliance by January 2025 and received a warning about future violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent under Article 6(1)(a) and Article 9(2)(a). The DPA found consent invalid due to the inherent power imbalance between public authorities and patients, making consent non-voluntary. The DPA referenced EDPB guidelines and Recital 43 regarding public authorities' limited ability to use consent.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDBP's guidelines 5/2020 regarding consent in accordance with regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Aarhus University Hospital published patient photos and health information on Instagram for marketing and recruitment purposes, claiming consent as legal basis. The Danish DPA found consent invalid due to the power imbalance between public healthcare providers and vulnerable patients. The processing violated Articles 5, 6(1)(a), and 9(2)(a) GDPR. The DPA issued serious criticism and ordered deletion of all patient posts.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly, finding the nature/gravity of infringement and categories of personal data affected as aggravating factors. Other factors were not systematically addressed in the decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that the National Audit Office's processing basis is Article 6(1)(e) (public task) with supplementary authority from the National Auditors Act Section 12(1). The Ministry of Justice had assessed this provision as compatible with GDPR, as processing is necessary for performance of a task in the interest of society.
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA conducted an inspection of the National Audit Office's processing of personal data during auditing activities. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) with supplementary authority from the National Auditors Act. The DPA also found compliance with data minimization principles through documented procedures and dialogue with audited authorities.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danish DPA investigated Digital Agency's use of JavaScript in MitID login system following citizen complaint about security risks. Agency conducted general risk assessment but failed to specifically assess JavaScript risks despite known security vulnerabilities. DPA found violations of accountability principle and security obligations, issuing criticism but no fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to critical national infrastructure context. Technical/organizational measures were aggravating due to insufficient risk assessment. Other factors not discussed.

a7_defendant_name: Ministry of the Interior and Health
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Danish DPA ruled that the Ministry of the Interior and Health could not refuse a data subject's request for access to CPR security log information based on resource concerns. The decision follows the CJEU ruling in case C-579/21 which established that log files containing search dates and purposes constitute personal data subject to Article 15 access rights. The DPA found that Section 22(2) of the Danish Data Protection Act does not permit refusal based on administrative burden but only for specific public interest considerations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Municipality claimed Article 6(1)(e) public task basis; DPA found processing necessary for official duties in notification case; DPA upheld municipality's assessment that legal basis was valid.
a75_case_summary: Helsingør Municipality processed illegally obtained wiretapping information in child protection case; DPA found processing lawful under Article 6(1)(e) as necessary for public task; DPA conducted fairness assessment weighing child protection interests against data protection rights; concluded processing was fair and compliant with GDPR principles.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: National Genome Center processed genetic data without consulting DPA despite DPIA showing high risk; DPA imposed temporary ban on data collection and restriction on processing; Violation of consultation requirement when high risk exists; Fine recommended due to seriousness but mitigated by NGC's cooperation and risk work quality.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered high risk to data subjects as aggravating; NGC's high quality risk work and active cooperation were mitigating factors; Other Art 83(2) factors not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Danske Bank failed to document proper deletion procedures across 400+ systems processing millions of individuals' data. The Danish DPA initiated an own-motion investigation after the bank self-reported deletion issues. The breach concerned fundamental GDPR principles including storage limitation and accountability. A DKK 10M fine was imposed considering the scale and basic nature of the violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (affecting many data subjects and basic principles). Mitigating factors included bank's efforts to limit damage and active cooperation. The fine was set to be effective, proportionate and deterrent.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Medicals Nordic used WhatsApp to transmit confidential health information and social security numbers of COVID-19 test subjects. Employees used private phones and WhatsApp groups where unauthorized personnel received sensitive data, including former employees who weren't removed from groups. The Danish DPA found inadequate security measures and intentional violations due to lack of risk assessments.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA emphasized that confidential health information about many citizens was processed insecurely and shared with unauthorized persons, including former employees. Violations were considered intentional due to lack of necessary risk assessments. The nature of sensitive data and intentional character were aggravating factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(a) but DPA found processing illegal as mere flipping from public registers did not fulfill necessity condition.
a75_case_summary: Czech DPA found company violated GDPR by scraping personal data from public registers without valid legal basis. Company failed to inform data subjects about processing and facilitate exercise of rights. Administrative proceeding resulted in CZK 500,000 fine and remedial measures order.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found this invalid without conducting a proper proportionality test balancing the data subject's rights against the public interest in information about criminal proceedings.
a75_case_summary: Individual posted partially anonymized criminal order containing personal data on Facebook. First instance DPA found GDPR violations and imposed CZK 10,000 fine. Municipal Court annulled decision due to failure to conduct proper proportionality test for legitimate interests. Appellate body returned case for new hearing requiring balance test between public interest and data protection rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no legal basis was needed but DPA found disclosure of complainant's expulsion to insurance companies violated Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1), and 9(1) as no valid legal basis existed under Articles 6 or 9 for this processing operation.
a75_case_summary: The Pancyprian Association of Motor Appraisers disclosed a member's expulsion to insurance companies without legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1), 9(1) and 31 due to unlawful processing of special category data (trade union membership) and lack of cooperation. The Association failed to demonstrate compliance or provide requested documentation during investigation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered lack of cooperation as aggravating and first-time offense as mitigating. No systematic Article 83(2) analysis was conducted beyond these factors.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Cabinet Office breached GDPR by sharing New Year Honours list with 1,097 recipients before official announcement. The data included home addresses and unshared postal details. The ICO found multiple Article 5 principle violations and failure to notify breach promptly. The processing lacked appropriate security measures and exceeded necessary data sharing.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The ICO systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity of breach, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, and sensitive data categories. Mitigating factors included cooperation with investigation, actions to mitigate damage, and prompt breach reporting. The overall assessment led to a £500,000 fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for employee monitoring system. DPA found this invalid as defendant failed to demonstrate necessity and proportionality, and did not consider less intrusive measures before implementation.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 2/2018 on Workplace Video Surveillance and Use of Biometric Systems;Opinion 2/2017 on Data Processing at Work;Opinion 06/2014 on Meaning of Legitimate Interests
a75_case_summary: KEO PLC implemented an upgraded employee card system with low-resolution photo capture for time tracking. DPA found violations of data minimization principle (installing camera without considering less intrusive measures) and storage limitation principle (7-year retention period). Defendant claimed legitimate interests but failed to demonstrate necessity and proportionality. DPA issued compliance order to suspend system and develop new measures with employee consultation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered Article 83(2) factors but did not impose fine. Cooperation with authority and compliance efforts were mitigating factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating. No systematic discussion of most factors occurred.

a7_defendant_name: Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful but DPA found violations of integrity/confidentiality principles and accountability obligation due to inability to locate insurance policy containing personal data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Personal data breach notification under Regulation 2016/679 WP 250 rev.1
a75_case_summary: Bank failed to locate complainant's insurance policy despite requests. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(f), 5(2), 15, 32, and 33 due to inadequate security measures leading to data unavailability, failure to demonstrate accountability, and lack of breach notification. Bank claimed policy might be misplaced but couldn't prove it still existed within their systems.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors systematically. Aggravating factors included nature of breach, manner authority informed, and infringement duration. Mitigating factors included cooperation with authority, actions to mitigate damage, and no financial benefit. Neutral factors included categories of data affected and number of data subjects.

a2_authority_name: Berlin Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Deutsche Wohnen SE violated multiple GDPR principles by storing tenant personal data indefinitely without proper purpose limitation, data minimization, or storage limitation. The housing company failed to implement adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure data protection. The Berlin DPA found systematic violations across Article 5 principles due to the company's failure to establish proper data retention policies and deletion concepts. The fine was reduced from initial proposal due to cooperation and remedial actions taken.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration, intentional/negligent character, technical measures, and previous infringements were aggravating. Actions to mitigate damage and cooperation were mitigating. Other mitigating factors included the company's efforts to improve compliance.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal basis under Article 6(1)(c) and (e); DPA found Article 6(1)(c) should be considered as legal basis instead of consent or public task; DPA emphasized candidates should be fully informed about processing.
a75_case_summary: The Examinations Service processed candidate data for statistical scoring methods without proper GDPR compliance. Violations included lack of processor contract under Article 28(1), failure to prove compliance under Article 24(1), and no prior consultation for regulatory measures under Article 36(4). The DPA issued reprimands but no fine due to mitigating factors including pseudonymization measures and absence of fraud.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered Article 83(2) factors: absence of fraud was mitigating; pseudonymization measures were mitigating; categories of data (non-special) were mitigating; detection via complaint rather than self-reporting was aggravating. No fine was imposed based on these considerations.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant stated there was no legal basis for integrating Google Analytics; the DPA found processing occurred without proper legal basis but did not explicitly invalidate any specific legal basis.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2021 on the interaction between the application of Article 3 and the provisions on international transfers according to Chapter V of the Regulation
a75_case_summary: The Cyprus DPA found violations by Cyprus News Agency regarding Google Analytics implementation. The defendant failed to demonstrate compliance with accountability principles (Article 5(2)) and did not ensure adequate protection for data transfers to the US (Article 44). The DPA issued reprimands and ordered compliance with the new EU-US Data Protection Framework or appropriate safeguards.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant used Facebook Pixel tool for advertising purposes;DPA found defendant failed to demonstrate compliance with data protection principles;No valid legal basis established for potential data transfers to US
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2021 on the interplay between Article 3 and Chapter V
a75_case_summary: Cypriot newspaper used Facebook Pixel tool;DPA found unlawful data transfers to US without adequate safeguards;Defendant failed to demonstrate compliance with accountability principle;Reprimands issued but no fine imposed due to new EU-US framework
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed perpetual consent and continuing doctor-patient relationship; DPA found no valid legal basis as processing was not necessary for medical diagnosis or treatment purposes under Article 9(2)(h); consent must be specific and cannot be perpetual.
a75_case_summary: A doctor accessed a former patient's medical records in Cyprus's national health system without authorization; DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 9(2)(h) as no doctor-patient relationship existed; defendant claimed perpetual consent and genuine interest but DPA rejected these arguments; reprimand issued instead of fine due to mitigating factors.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating factors included sensitive data access and multiple incidents; mitigating factors included defendant no longer contracted with NHS, cooperation with authority, and no previous infringements; overall assessment led to reprimand instead of fine.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Cyprus SA issued reprimand to financial controller for failing to notify complainant about erasure request action within GDPR timeframe. Controller claimed emails were lost due to volume and complainant used wrong email address. Commissioner found infringement of Articles 12(3) and 24(1) GDPR due to lack of proper procedures for handling data subject rights.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed. Aggravating: duration of breach, lack of appropriate procedures. Mitigating: no previous violations, cooperation with authority, remedial actions taken. Neutral: categories of personal data affected.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed identification documents were needed to verify identity for data subject access requests under Recital 64 GDPR. The DPA found this excessive as email verification was sufficient and collecting IDs solely for potential requests violates data minimization principles.
a75_case_summary: Technius Ltd violated GDPR by requesting excessive government ID for access requests and inadequate breach communication. The DPA found requesting IDs violated data minimization principles as email verification was sufficient. Blog post breach notification was insufficient despite controller's claims about scale. A reprimand was issued considering mitigating factors including first violation and prompt compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating factors included no previous violations, prompt compliance with requests, and staff training measures. Aggravating factors included inadequate breach communication methods and excessive identification procedures given special category data processing.

a7_defendant_name: Council of Registration of Hairdressers and Barbers of Cyprus
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed employee consent as legal basis for CCTV monitoring. The DPA found consent invalid due to power imbalance in employment relationship, citing EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 that consent cannot be freely given in employer-employee contexts.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 3/2019 on processing of personal data through video devices;EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent
a75_case_summary: The Cyprus Hairdressers and Barbers Registration Board installed CCTV in office monitoring employees and visitors without proper legal basis. The DPA found consent invalid due to employer-employee power imbalance. Orders were issued to permanently stop CCTV operation, delete recordings, and provide implementation proof within 2 weeks.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: cooperation with authority and absence of previous incidents were mitigating; lack of appropriate legal basis was aggravating. No systematic discussion of all factors occurred.

a2_authority_name: Commissioner for Personal Data Protection in Cyprus
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f); DPA found processing lawful since data was manifestly made public by data subjects on public sources like Google; purpose remained unchanged from original publication of business contact details
a75_case_summary: Senira Limited operated nicelocal.com website collecting business information from public sources; failed to respond to data subject erasure requests within GDPR timeframe; violated Article 12(3) by not acting on requests within one month; violated Article 31 by failing to cooperate with supervisory authority's investigation requests
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; mitigating factors: requests eventually satisfied, no harm occurred, no sensitive data; aggravating factors: increasing complaints, lack of appropriate procedures, lack of response to preliminary decision order

a2_authority_name: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest for journalistic purposes; DPA found publication of photographs excessive and not necessary for public information right; violated minimization principle and invalidated legitimate interest basis
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guideline 4/2022 on the calculation of administrative sanctions on the basis of the GDPR 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Newspaper publisher Breikot Management Ltd published photographs of three complainants in four articles about their family architectural firm continuing public works despite conviction. DPA found violation of Articles 5(1)(c) and 6 GDPR as photographs exceeded journalistic necessity and minimization principle. Administrative Court upheld violation but annulled fine amount, leading to review that maintained original €3,000 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating; negligent character, mitigation actions, cooperation, and first offense as mitigating; data categories as neutral. Fine maintained at €3,000 after review of aggravating and mitigating factors.

a2_authority_name: Office of the Commissioner for Personal Data Protection
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for credit assessment purposes; the DPA found violations of accuracy and storage limitation principles due to retention of data beyond legal period; key reasoning was that technical limitations and lack of resources do not excuse non-compliance with GDPR obligations.
a75_case_summary: The Housing Finance Organization retained complainant's loan application data beyond the 6-month retention period; inaccurate data from a 2020 rejected application was used in assessing a 2023 application; the DPA found violations of accuracy, storage limitation, and accountability principles; technical limitations and resource constraints were rejected as justifications for non-compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors; aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringement, intentional/negligent character, and failure to implement measures; mitigating factors included cooperation with authority and actions to mitigate damage; neutral factor was categories of data affected.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian Insurance Bureau fined €101,000 for security failures leading to data leak of over 1 million vehicle owners' personal data. Agency found inadequate technical/organizational measures under Article 32 and failure to prescribe maximum retention periods under Article 5(1)(e). Fine reduced due to defendant's public authority status under national implementation law.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed include nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, categories of personal data affected as aggravating, and other mitigating factors (public authority status). Most factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian Insurance Bureau fined €101,000 for GDPR violations. HUO failed to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures under Article 32, compromising personal data security. Additionally, HUO violated Article 5(1)(e) by not prescribing maximum retention periods for personal data. The fine amount considered HUO's status as a legal entity with public authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controllers claimed consent as legal basis for cookie processing but DPA found consent invalid due to cookie banner not allowing clear distinction between purposes and processing occurring before consent was given
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA imposed nine fines totaling €51,000 on controllers for GDPR violations. Gambling operators fined €15,000-€20,000 for invalid cookie consent and transparency violations. Hotels and shops fined €500-€4,000 for inadequate CCTV signage violating national implementation law requirements.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent and legitimate interests as legal bases. The DPA found consent invalid after termination of contractual relationship and legitimate interests invalid as the data subject did not reasonably expect further processing.
a75_case_summary: Bank X processed applicant's personal data for marketing purposes after termination of contractual relationship. The DPA found no legal basis as consent was invalid after relationship ended and legitimate interests did not apply since data subject did not reasonably expect further processing. Violations of Article 5(1)(b) purpose limitation and Article 6(1) lawful basis were established. No corrective measures were imposed as processing had already ceased.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed no specific legal basis but argued the photos were publicly available on social media. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6 for publishing the photos in the specific article context, as it did not relate to the applicant's political activities or media statements.
a75_case_summary: A media company published photos of a political party member from her private Facebook profile in an article about personal relationships. The DPA found the publication lacked lawful purpose and legal basis under Articles 5 and 6 GDPR, as the content did not relate to her political activities. The company was ordered to remove the photos from its portal and inform the DPA of compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a7_defendant_name: Tourist Board of the City of X
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for photography at public event. DPA found legitimate interest valid for general event photography but invalid for using individual child's photo for promotional purposes without consent. DPA determined consent under Article 6(1)(a) was required but not obtained.
a75_case_summary: Tourist Board organized public sports event and photographed attendees including minor child. Used child's individual photo for promotional purposes without consent. DPA found legitimate interest valid for general event photography but invalid for individual promotional use requiring consent. Controller removed photos after complaint but violated Articles 5 and 6 GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (using child's photo without consent), categories of data as aggravating (child's personal data), and remedial actions as mitigating (removing photos after complaint). Other factors not systematically discussed under Article 83(2).

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA rejected complaint against real estate agency regarding publication of photo showing complainant during apartment viewing. Agency determined the photo did not constitute personal data as the person was wearing a mask and jacket, making identification impossible for an average person. No GDPR violation found as the data did not meet the definition of personal data under Article 4(1).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for survey calls. DPA found this invalid as applicant was not a client/user, no balance test was conducted, and number was in Do Not Call Registry. Human error admission proved lack of appropriate protection measures.
a75_case_summary: Company x called applicant's phone number for survey purposes while number was registered in Do Not Call Registry. DPA found processing unlawful as legitimate interest claim invalid without proper balance test and applicant not being client. Company admitted human error, proving inadequate protection measures. Violations found of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(f), 6, 14, and 17.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Agency for the Protection of Personal Data
a7_defendant_name: car sales and service center based in Zagreb
