a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA conducted ex officio supervision of car sales and service center's CCTV system; Found violation of Article 27(1) of national GDPR implementation law for failing to mark video surveillance areas; Imposed HRK 30,000 administrative fine deemed effective, proportional and deterrent; Fine paid to state budget.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA rejected complaint alleging GDPR violations by municipal office. Office received anonymous letter with intimate photos but couldn't identify data subject. DPA found office acted correctly by refusing access/deletion requests since identity couldn't be established. No evidence of unauthorized data sharing or media publication of personal data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal obligation under Budget Act; DPA found no legal basis for publishing names in litigation list; Special regulations require only concise description of disputes, not personal data.
a75_case_summary: Health Center published financial statements including names of litigation opponents on website; DPA found no legal basis for publishing personal data under Budget Act requirements; Controller ordered to delete personal data and implement protective measures; Processing violated GDPR principles of lawfulness, purpose limitation, and data minimization.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest as legal basis for publishing anonymized leave schedule;DPA found no legitimate interest proven as proportionality test was not conducted;DPA determined no legal basis existed under Article 6
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA found Social Welfare Center violated GDPR by publishing employee leave schedule containing names on bulletin board;Center claimed legitimate interest but failed to conduct proportionality test;DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 and violation of Article 5 principles;Order issued to prohibit further processing without legal basis
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for compliance with legal obligations under the Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act. The DPA found Article 6(1)(c) valid as the company was obliged to establish customer identity through ID card collection. The processing was deemed lawful for fulfilling specific legal obligations.
a75_case_summary: The Croatian DPA rejected a complaint against company Y, an electronic money institution, which requested a copy of the applicant's ID card for customer due diligence under anti-money laundering regulations. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) as necessary for compliance with legal obligations under the Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act. The company properly informed the applicant about processing purposes and legal basis as required by Article 13. No GDPR violations were found as the processing was fair, lawful, and transparent.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Individual installed CCTV cameras that excessively monitored public road area beyond property protection needs. Croatian DPA found violation of national GDPR implementation law Article 32 prohibiting public area monitoring by private entities. Ordered camera angle adjustment and deletion of unlawfully collected recordings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found the proportionality test inadequate and failed to prove necessity or proper balancing against data subject rights. The controller incorrectly cited national laws as legal basis instead of GDPR provisions.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers (WP 243 rev.01);Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines (WP 253)
a75_case_summary: The Croatian DPA fined a business data provider _ d.o.o. €40,000 for multiple GDPR violations. The company processed craft owners' personal data without proper legal basis under Article 6(1)(f), failed transparency obligations under Articles 12-14, maintained inadequate records under Article 30, and appointed a DPO with conflict of interest under Article 38. Violations were discovered through citizen complaints and DPA inspection.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to prolonged violations since 2018. Intentional character was aggravating for transparency violations, negligent for others. Previous infringements were aggravating. Cooperation was aggravating due to initial non-cooperation. No damage mitigation was neutral.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Officers;Guidelines on the application and setting of administrative fines
a75_case_summary: Croatian DPA found controller violated GDPR Articles 37(7) and 38(6) by appointing DPO with conflict of interest (company procurator) and failing to publish DPO contact details on website. The DPA determined procurator role involves determining purposes/means of processing, creating conflict with DPO advisory role. Fine imposed based on coordinated EDPB activity investigating DPO positions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically applied Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: nature/duration of infringement, poor cooperation with authority, failure to resolve conflict of interest. Mitigating: negligent not intentional conduct, actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements. Neutral: manner authority became aware.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on contractual relations but the DPA found no valid contract existed since the data subject never visited the office or signed the application, making Article 6(1)(b) invalid.
a75_case_summary: A telecommunications operator illegally processed a complainant's personal data by transferring her mobile number without consent or valid legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 due to lack of proper identification procedures and insufficient organizational measures. The controller had previous similar violations and was ordered to improve its data protection policies and pay a reduced fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: duration was mitigating (short period), actions to mitigate damage were mitigating (corrected error quickly), technical measures were aggravating (insufficient controls), previous infringements were aggravating (repeat offender), and cooperation was neutral. Other mitigating factors included no financial benefit and stopping violation voluntarily.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legal bases under Art 6(1)(a) consent, (c) legal obligation, and (f) legitimate interests. DPA found none valid as data provision to German authorities was not necessary for employment contract, consent was not specific to this purpose, and legitimate interests did not outweigh data subject's rights given factual errors.
a75_case_summary: Company D. JSC unlawfully provided employee's personal data to German transport authorities for a traffic violation that occurred while employee was on sick leave and vehicle was no longer in company's possession. DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and (b) with Articles 6(1) as data was processed without valid legal basis. Fine imposed due to intentional violation, irreparable consequences, and failure to correct erroneous information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating: intentional nature, irreparable consequences, failure to take corrective measures. Mitigating: cooperation with authority, no previous infringements, reimbursement of fine. Neutral: categories of personal data affected.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) but the DPA found this invalid as the data subjects' interests took precedence over the political party's interest in participating in elections. No valid consent was obtained and no other legal bases under Article 6(1) were applicable.
a75_case_summary: A Bulgarian political party unlawfully processed complainants' personal data by including them in election registration lists without consent. Handwriting expertise confirmed signatures were forged. The DPA found violations of Articles 6(1), 5(2) and 24 GDPR due to lack of legal basis and inadequate organizational measures. The party was fined 25,000 BGN and ordered to implement proper data protection measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included: violation of three individuals' rights; processing of identification numbers; lack of cooperation with DPA; previous identical violations; and the completed nature of infringements. No mitigating circumstances were found. The violation was not the first for this controller.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on error/mistake rather than a valid legal basis. The DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and held the processing unlawful.
a75_case_summary: A telecommunications operator illegally processed complainant's personal data (name, ID number, phone number) by transferring her mobile number without consent or valid legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a) and 6 due to inadequate identification procedures and organizational measures. The operator corrected the error quickly but had previous similar violations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating: violation stopped quickly, no damages, self-correction. Aggravating: insufficient technical/organizational measures, repeat offender. Neutral: cooperation with authority.

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for property protection and child safety. DPA found legitimate interest valid as property protection and child safety interests outweigh data subjects' interests given conflict relations and vandalism evidence.
a75_case_summary: Complaint alleged illegal CCTV in co-owned property. DPA found video surveillance lawful under legitimate interest (Art 6(1)(f)) as controller had majority ownership share and demonstrated need for property protection and child safety. DPA cited conflict relations, vandalism evidence, and information stickers as justifying surveillance of common areas.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a2_authority_name: Commission for the Protection of Personal Data
a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed journalistic purposes but the DPA found the processing unlawful as it violated Article 5 principles; the DPA determined the processing was not done lawfully, fairly, or transparently regardless of journalistic purpose claims.
a75_case_summary: A journalist published a medical diploma and criminal record containing personal data of a doctor on Facebook; the DPA found violations of Article 5 principles regarding lawfulness, fairness, and accuracy; both the journalist and the doctor who provided the data received official warnings; the DPA considered the short publication duration mitigating but the inclusion of third-party data aggravating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly; aggravating factors included nature/gravity and categories of data affected; mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, no previous infringements, and other mitigating circumstances; the discussion was not systematic.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Interlocutory decision on language of proceedings in complaint against IAB Europe regarding GDPR violations in digital advertising. Belgian DPA maintains French as procedural language but allows parties to use French, Dutch, or English. Decision will be issued in French with Dutch and English translations provided simultaneously.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Defendant failed to respond to data subject's erasure request within required timeframe and continued sending promotional emails. DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 17.1 GDPR. Ordered defendant to comply with erasure request within 30 days and report outcome to DPA.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Recruitment agency failed to respond to data subject's repeated requests for data erasure under Article 17 GDPR. Despite multiple contacts from complainant requesting deletion, defendant continued communications. Dispute Chamber found potential violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 17.1 GDPR and ordered compliance with erasure request within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found controller violated GDPR by failing to comply with data subject's erasure request for email address receiving unwanted marketing emails. Controller requested additional email addresses instead of deleting the problematic address, violating data minimization and accountability principles. The DPA ordered compliance with erasure request within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed consent but DPA found consent not free due to lack of alternative; DPA also examined legitimate interests and found data subject interests prevailed; no valid legal basis established.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent within the meaning of Regulation 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Retailer required electronic ID card scanning for loyalty card creation without alternative. DPA found violations of data minimization (Article 5(1)(c)) due to processing irrelevant data like gender and national register number, and no valid legal basis (Article 6) as consent wasn't free and legitimate interests didn't prevail. Also found transparency violations (Article 13) regarding legal basis and storage period information.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to fundamental principle violation and considerable impact on all customers. Also discussed categories of data as aggravating due to national register number processing. No other factors discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed forwarding was unintentional error; DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6; Legitimate interest test failed necessity and balancing requirements.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 1/2010 on concepts of controller and processor
a75_case_summary: Accounting firm mistakenly emailed complainant's personal data to former business associate; DPA found violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 5(1)(b), 5(1)(c), and 6 GDPR due to lack of legal basis; Reprimand issued to accounting firm; Second defendant ordered to permanently cease processing the email.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating; intentional/negligent character as mitigating due to human error; actions to mitigate damage as mitigating; previous infringements as mitigating as first offense; cooperation as mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent as legal basis for processing candidate data. The DPA found consent valid for candidates who explicitly consented, and no violation of Articles 6 and 5(2) was established.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation on the appointment of a Data Protection Officer;Guidelines for Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: A recruitment consultancy failed to properly respond to a data deletion request and had incomplete transparency documentation. The DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4, 13.2(b), 30.1(d) and 30.1(g) but noted the defendant's cooperative efforts and modest business size. A reprimand was issued without financial penalty.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the defendant's modest enterprise size, collaborative spirit, and pre-procedure compliance efforts as mitigating factors. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found controller violated GDPR by failing to comply with data subject's erasure request. Complainant requested deletion of email address used for unsolicited marketing emails on November 9 and 14, 2022, but continued receiving emails on January 16, 2023. The DPA ordered the controller to comply with the erasure request within 30 days and notify the Authority of the result.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on his public function as mayor. The DPA found the reuse of citizen contact data for electoral purposes incompatible with the original purpose of collection, violating Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(4) GDPR.
a75_case_summary: A municipal mayor reused citizen contact data collected during his official duties for electoral campaigning. The DPA found this violated purpose limitation principles under Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(4) GDPR. The breach was considered serious due to the electoral context and defendant's public position. A €5,000 fine and reprimand were imposed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to fundamental principle violation. Intentional character was aggravating as processing was deliberate. Data categories were neutral as only identification data. Other aggravating factors included defendant's public position and electoral context.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found consent was valid legal basis for processing candidate data; defendant obtained explicit consent from candidates already in database before GDPR via mailing and from new applicants at time of application.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation on the appointment of a Data Protection Officer;Guidelines for Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: Defendant failed to properly respond to data erasure request within required timeframe and provide clear reasons for non-compliance. DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4, 13.2(b), 30.1(d) and 30.1(g) regarding transparency obligations and record keeping. Defendant demonstrated cooperation and made improvements during proceedings. A reprimand was issued considering defendant's modest size and collaborative spirit.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered defendant's modest enterprise size, collaborative spirit, and efforts to improve compliance as mitigating factors. No systematic Article 83(2) discussion was conducted.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for strictly necessary cookies; DPA found consent invalid for non-functional cookies but validated legitimate interest for functional cookies; Key reasoning centered on cookie walls being acceptable only for strictly necessary cookies.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Opinion 5/2019 on the interactions between the ePrivacy Directive and the GDPR;WP29 Guidelines on Consent within the meaning of Regulation 2016/679;WP29 Guidelines on Transparency within the meaning of Regulation (EU) 2016/679;EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent within the meaning of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found violations regarding cookie consent and transparency. Defendant placed cookies without prior information and used unclear privacy policy language. DPA issued reprimand and compliance order for processing register. Case involved cross-border complaint from German data subject through OSS mechanism.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; cooperation was mitigating. Other factors were not discussed systematically.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation 01/2020 of 17 January 2020 relating to the processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes
a75_case_summary: Former customer complained about continued marketing calls after requesting data deletion. Defendant confirmed deletion but complainant alleged continued calls. DPA found potential breaches of right to object and erasure provisions. Ordered defendant to comply with data subject rights within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued warning and compliance order against public authority Y for failing to properly respond to data subject's access request regarding National Register consultation. Defendant consulted complainant's data but failed to provide complete information about the consultation and identity of the professional who accessed it within GDPR timelines. The DPA found potential violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 15 regarding access rights and ordered compliance within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest as legal basis for cookies used for website functionality and statistics collection. The DPA found this invalid as consent is required for non-essential cookies under Article 129 WEC and Articles 6-7 GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Opinion 04/2012 on exemption from consent requirement for cookies;Guidelines on transparency under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA found a legal news website violated GDPR transparency and consent requirements. The website failed to provide proper privacy information in required languages, used pre-ticked cookie consent boxes, and lacked valid legal basis for analytics cookies. The DPA imposed a €15,000 fine considering the negligent nature, duration of infringements, and the website's 35,000 monthly readers.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including duration (aggravating), negligent character (aggravating), measures taken to mitigate (mitigating), and cooperation with authority (mitigating). The fine was set at €15,000 considering these factors and the controller's turnover.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(c) GDPR (legal obligation) under the Royal Decree of 25 March 2003 and Regulation (EU) 2019/1157. The DPA found this legal basis valid as there is a legal obligation to include fingerprints in identity cards.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: A municipality processed eight fingerprints per hand for eID creation instead of the legally permitted one fingerprint per hand. The DPA found the processing lawful under Article 6(1)(c) GDPR due to legal obligations, but noted transparency issues regarding Article 13 information provision. The DPA found no violations of purpose limitation or data minimization principles as the extra fingerprints were temporarily processed for quality selection and destroyed within three months.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Employee complained about company's refusal to provide copies of performance sheets despite multiple requests. DPA found defendant violated Articles 15 and 12 GDPR by only offering on-site consultation instead of providing copies. Defendant failed to justify refusal or invoke GDPR exceptions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian bank failed to respond to data access request within GDPR-mandated one-month timeframe; complainants sought all personal data including reasons for account closure; DPA found violation of Article 15 access rights but dismissed complaint regarding completeness of response.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian municipality consulted complainant's national register file without explanation. Complainant exercised right of access regarding purpose of consultation but received no response. Litigation Chamber ordered municipality to comply with access request within 30 days. This is a prima facie decision allowing defendant to request full merits proceeding.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Notification of Personal Data Breaches under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines for Data Protection Officers (DPO)
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found defendant violated Article 38(6) GDPR by appointing DPO who also served as head of Compliance, Risk Management and Internal Audit departments, creating conflict of interest. The DPA ordered corrective measures and imposed €50,000 fine. Defendant's procedural challenges were dismissed as rights of defense were respected.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors discussed: nature/gravity/duration (aggravating), intentional/negligent character (aggravating), categories of data affected (aggravating). Other factors not discussed. Fine based on serious negligence, large-scale processing impacting millions, and duration from May 2018 to February 2020.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued reprimand to city for failing to implement proper access controls and logging for National Register consultations. The city could not justify a specific photo consultation or demonstrate compliance with security obligations. DPA found breaches of accountability, security, and purpose limitation principles, but noted remedial measures were being implemented.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors without systematic structure. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; technical measures were aggravating; data categories were aggravating; cooperation was mitigating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; other factors were mitigating due to remedial actions taken.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued preliminary decision ordering defendant to respond to data subject's access request. Complainant sent access requests in September and October 2022 with no response. DPA found potential violations of Articles 12 and 15 GDPR and ordered compliance within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation 01/2020 of January 17, 2020 relating to the processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes
a75_case_summary: Defendant Y failed to honor complainant's multiple requests to unsubscribe from marketing emails since 2020. The DPA found violations of Article 21 (right to object) and Articles 5.2/24 (accountability principle). Defendant showed disregard for obligations by responding "Go ahead!" to complaint threat. The decision orders compliance with right to object and issues reprimand.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed consent from users was valid legal basis for processing non-users' data. DPA found consent invalid as only data subjects can consent to their own data processing. DPA also examined and rejected legitimate interest as legal basis for processing non-users' data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 5/2009 on online social networking;Opinion 06/2014 on the concept of legitimate interest;Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data by camera
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found social media platform Y violated GDPR by processing non-users' personal data without legal basis through "invite a friend" functionality. Platform claimed user consent justified processing third-party data, but DPA ruled only data subjects can consent to their own processing. DPA also rejected legitimate interest basis as processing exceeded necessary scope and duration. Fine of €50,000 imposed for violations of Articles 5 and 6.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating due to serious lack of legal basis. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating as defendant was aware of issues. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as defendant removed pre-ticked options. Categories of data affected was aggravating due to processing non-users' data. Cooperation was neutral as defendant cooperated but maintained incorrect legal position.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legal obligations under the Act of 18 September 2017 and Royal Decree of 30 July 2018. The DPA found this legal basis valid for the first defendant's processing activities in maintaining the UBO register.
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA dismissed a complaint against the Federal Public Service Finance regarding incorrect UBO register data, finding they took reasonable measures to ensure accuracy. However, the DPA issued a warning to a nonprofit organization for failing to provide adequate information to a data subject when collecting their national register number for UBO registration purposes, violating Article 13 GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Interim procedural decision regarding language of proceedings; Belgian DPA changes case language from French to Dutch; Parties retain right to use French, Dutch or English in submissions; No substantive GDPR violations addressed in this interim decision.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint regarding failure to erase personal data (email address) used for unsolicited marketing emails. Defendant explained complainant had two accounts with different email addresses; initial erasure request only covered one address. Disputes Chamber found defendant complied properly and no GDPR infringement occurred.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Defendant failed to respond to data subject's access request within required timeframe. The defendant acknowledged the delay but claimed it was unintentional due to employee absence. The DPA found violations of Articles 15.1, 12.3 and 12.4 GDPR regarding the right of access. The defendant implemented organizational measures to prevent future occurrences.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the defendant's remedial actions and organizational improvements as mitigating factors. The defendant had begun preparing a response with legal assistance and created a shared mailbox system for access requests. These efforts led to a reprimand being deemed sufficient sanction.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed regarding alleged theft of medical documents from personnel file and failure to guarantee file integrity. Against defendant 1 (supervisor), insufficient evidence of GDPR breach regarding alleged unlawful appropriation and copying of data. Against defendant 2 (controller), missing documents did not constitute major personal impact and complainant failed to provide evidence that documents should have been in file or were improperly handled.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Defendant published complainant's name, address and photo on personal website without consent. Complainant repeatedly requested erasure but defendant failed to comply despite promises and formal DPA order. DPA found violations of Articles 12.3, 12.4, 17.1 and 31 GDPR for failing to respond to erasure requests and cooperate with authority.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating due to core GDPR rights violation and prolonged duration. Intentional/negligent character was aggravating due to ignoring requests and orders. Cooperation was aggravating due to non-response. Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating as defendant eventually deleted data. Other factors not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found financial institution violated Article 15 GDPR by failing to provide complete access to personal data. Defendant consulted three files but only provided complete data from its own file, referring complainant to other controllers for remaining data. DPA ordered defendant to comply with access request within 30 days and provide copies of all personal data processed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed processing was due to human error; DPA found no legal basis under Article 6 applied; Processing was unlawful as none of Article 6 conditions were met
a75_case_summary: Defendant sent marketing emails to complainant due to human error mixing email addresses; Complainant exercised right of access but received inadequate response; DPA found breaches of Articles 5,6,12,15,24 GDPR; Fine imposed for inadequate response to data subject rights and unlawful processing
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors; Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; Intentional/negligent character was aggravating; Actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; Technical/organizational measures were aggravating; Other factors not discussed

a7_defendant_name: Federal Public Service for Mobility and Transport
a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant processed data based on public task under Belgian law; DPA found processing violated purpose limitation as commercial reuse exceeded authorized public interest purposes; consent from insurance customers could not validate processing prohibited by Belgian Royal Decree.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Overview of the concepts of controller/processor in light of Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found FPS Mobility violated GDPR by allowing insurance companies to access vehicle registration data through Informex NV for commercial premium quotes. The processing violated purpose limitation (Article 5(1)(b)) as it exceeded authorized public interest purposes under Belgian law. While violations of Articles 5(1)(b) and 6(1) were established, no fine was imposed due to good faith reliance on prior Privacy Commission advice. The defendant also received a reprimand for transparency violations (Articles 12-14).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed processing was based on employment contract regulations. DPA found Art 6(1)(b) invalid since employment contract terminated in 2021 and publication not necessary for contract execution. Art 6(1)(f) invalid as publication not necessary for recruitment purpose and interests did not outweigh complainant's rights. Art 6(1)(a) invalid due to lack of free consent in employment context.
a75_case_summary: Former employee complained about photo published on company website for recruitment without consent. DPA found processing unlawful as no valid legal basis under Art 6. Defendant responded to erasure request but did not comply. DPA ordered defendant to erase data and comply with right to erasure under Art 17.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under legal obligation but DPA found no valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and invalidated consent under Article 8 for children's data processing without parental consent.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA imposed €1000 fine on school for conducting well-being survey of minors via Smartschool without valid legal basis under Article 6(1) and violating Article 8 parental consent requirements. The DPA rejected defendant's claim of government exemption from fines, finding violations of data minimization principle (Article 5(1)(c)) and special protections for children's data.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered nature/gravity as aggravating (Articles 5(1)(c),6(1),8 violated), defendant's non-profit status as mitigating, and willingness to implement anonymous surveys as mitigating. Duration was limited to single survey event.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was necessary for public task under Article 6(1)(e). The DPA found the title of nobility was not necessary for identification purposes and therefore violated the necessity requirement of Article 6(1)(e).
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25, Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found a public administration violated GDPR by refusing to remove nobility title from identity card. The DPA held the title was not necessary for identification purposes, violating data minimization and purpose limitation principles. The processing lacked lawful basis under Article 6(1)(e) as it wasn't necessary for public task. The DPA issued a reprimand and ordered removal of the title within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed the nature and gravity of the violation as aggravating, noting the fundamental importance of minimization and purpose limitation principles and the prolonged duration since 2016. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically addressed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Report on the work undertaken by the Cookie Banner Taskforce
a75_case_summary: Complaint alleged invalid consent for cookie processing on website due to missing reject-all button. DPA found defendant had remedied the issue before complaint reached Litigation Chamber by ensuring no non-essential cookies were pre-selected and adding reject functionality. Case dismissed without action as the violation no longer existed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Report on the work undertaken by the Cookie Banner Taskforce
a75_case_summary: Complaint alleged GDPR and ePrivacy violations regarding cookie consent mechanism on defendant's website, specifically that consent withdrawal was not as easy as giving consent. The Litigation Chamber found the violation no longer existed as the website had implemented proper cookie banner functionality with reject-all button and cookie settings URL before the complaint was transferred. Case was dismissed without action as the subject matter had been resolved.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) for processing electoral data to identify new residents for campaign purposes. The DPA found this invalid as the processing was not necessary for electoral purposes and the controller's interests did not outweigh data subjects' rights, especially given the use of knowledge acquired through other professional/political roles.
a75_case_summary: A local politician processed voter data from electoral rolls to create a list of new residents for targeted campaign mailings. The DPA found violations of purpose limitation (using 2012 electoral data for 2018 elections) and legitimate interests basis (using knowledge from other roles). Transparency violations occurred as the letter lacked proper controller identification and information about data processing methods.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors including seriousness of infringement (aggravating), technical/organizational measures (aggravating), duration (mixed - short processing period but using old data), and deterrent effect (aggravating). Financial capacity was considered mitigating, leading to fine reduction from €5000 to €3000.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: recommendation of the Data Protection Authority nr 01/2020 of January 17, 2020 relating to the processing of personal data for direct marketing purposes
a75_case_summary: A former customer requested deletion of his personal data from a commercial company. The company partially complied but failed to delete data from a separate prospect database. The Litigation Chamber found violations of Article 17.1 GDPR (right to erasure) and Article 12.3 GDPR (failure to provide information on measures taken). The Chamber issued a reprimand rather than a fine, considering partial fulfillment as mitigating and the limited impact.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The Litigation Chamber considered partial fulfillment of the complainant's request as a mitigating circumstance. The absence of database linkage was not considered mitigating as the controller should have conducted proper searches. No other Article 83(2) factors were systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint due to invalid representation. Complainant was represented by French e-reputation company X3 which did not meet GDPR Article 80.1 requirements for non-profit organizations with public interest objectives. The Chamber did not rule on the substantive delisting request regarding a 2007 news article about complainant's conviction.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – right of access
a75_case_summary: The case concerns a former employee's right of access request regarding his work email mailbox. The Belgian DPA found the request was excessive as it covered 8+ years of emails used by multiple employees and contained sensitive health data of disabled service users. The defendant lawfully refused access but failed to properly demonstrate the excessive nature of the request, violating Article 12(5) GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were not discussed in the decision. The DPA issued only a reprimand for the Article 12(5) violation, finding it not serious enough for a fine.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued prima facie decision against non-profit organization Y for failing to respond to data erasure request. Complainant requested deletion on July 27, 2023 to stop unsolicited mail but continued receiving communications. DPA found infringement of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 17.1 GDPR and ordered compliance with erasure request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the municipality's processing was based on Article 6(1)(e) GDPR (public task) as necessary for measures to prevent coronavirus spread. The defendant acted within this legal basis when contacting volunteers for mask distribution.
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA dismissed complaints against a municipal alderman who used volunteer email addresses obtained through the municipality's general email for mask distribution coordination. The DPA found the defendant acted within the original public interest purpose (Article 6(1)(e)) and complied with purpose limitation, data minimization, and storage limitation principles. No GDPR infringement was found as the processing was necessary for coronavirus prevention measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR for processing complainant's data to understand invoice origin. DPA found all three conditions satisfied: legitimate purpose (understanding invoice), necessity (no alternative means), and balancing test favored controller given reasonable expectations.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint against former employer's consultant who shared employee data with pension insurer to understand invoice. DPA found legitimate interest basis valid under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR as processing was necessary for understanding invoice origin and reasonable expectation existed. No GDPR violation found.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed processing based on Article 6.1.f GDPR (legitimate interests). DPA found no GDPR violation and dismissed complaint as manifestly unfounded.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights – Right of access
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed regarding FPS Finance's refusal to provide cadastral income comparison data of third parties. DPA found no GDPR violation as complaint did not concern complainant's personal data processing. Right of access under Article 15 GDPR cannot be used to obtain third-party personal data. Complaint deemed manifestly unfounded.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found that processing was justified under Article 9(2)(h) GDPR for public health purposes and Article 17.3 GDPR exemption for public interest in public health/social services.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint regarding erasure request for youth care motivation document. Found Article 17 right to erasure not applicable as document contained professional assessments in public health context under Article 9(2)(h). DPA cannot assess accuracy of mental well-being evaluations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for legal defense and business continuity. The DPA found legitimate interest valid only for data less than 5 years old, invalid for older data due to lack of necessity and proportionality.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 2/2017 on data processing in the workplace;Opinion 06/2014 on the notion of legitimate interest
a75_case_summary: Former employee complained about employer's data recovery from laptop after dismissal. DPA found legitimate interest basis valid only for data less than 5 years old due to pending litigation. Violations found for right of access, erasure, restriction, objection, and lack of processor contract. Compliance order issued with €7500 fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were discussed briefly. Nature/gravity/duration was aggravating. Intentional character was aggravating. Other factors were not discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint against bank and collection agency regarding alleged failure to respond to access and erasure requests. Case was closed without action due to insufficient evidence and being manifestly excessive under Article 57.4 GDPR. The complaint was filed over 2 years after the alleged incidents with no valid justification for delay.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consultation was necessary for sending eco-checks to correct address. The DPA found the National Register consultation was not for notarial tasks but common employer activities, lacking legal basis under Article 6 GDPR.
a75_case_summary: A notary consulted the National Register to verify an employee's address for sending eco-checks post-employment. The DPA found this consultation violated Article 6 GDPR as it was not for notarial tasks but common employer activities. The defendant received a reprimand considering mitigating factors including isolated nature, low impact, and implemented compliance measures.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered aggravating factors including defendant's professional status requiring exemplary compliance. Mitigating factors included isolated breach, low data sensitivity, available through other sources, and implemented compliance measures. The breach was deemed not structural.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint regarding access request and erasure refusal. Defendant initially failed to respond to access request but later agreed to provide access. Erasure refusal was justified under Article 17(3)(e) GDPR as processing was necessary for potential future legal claims.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA dismissed a complaint about an email forwarding incident involving a real estate appraiser. The Disputes Chamber found the complaint lacked major social/personal impact and was a side dispute to broader property acquisition litigation. No GDPR violations were assessed on merits due to expediency dismissal.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on legitimate interest from previous contacts, but the DPA found the electoral purpose incompatible with the original purpose of responding to citizen inquiries, violating purpose limitation and lawfulness principles.
a75_case_summary: A Belgian politician used email addresses collected through his mayoral secretariat for electoral campaigning. The DPA found this violated purpose limitation and lawfulness principles under GDPR. The defendant also failed to implement proper security measures, resulting in a data breach when all recipients were visible. A €5000 fine was imposed considering the public official's role as aggravating.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: nature/gravity/duration was aggravating; intentional/negligent character was mitigating (non-deliberate error); cooperation was aggravating (failed to share conclusions); other factors were aggravating (defendant's public role). Technical measures were aggravating due to inadequate security.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed Article 6(1)(c) (legal obligation) as legal basis for accessing complete household composition history. The DPA found this basis invalid as the processing was disproportionate and not necessary for compliance with the legal obligation, violating the minimization principle.
a75_case_summary: A family allowance fund accessed complainant's personal data through complete household composition history of complainant's son via National Register. DPA found violation of Articles 6, 5(1)(c), 24 and 5(2) GDPR as processing was disproportionate and lacked valid legal basis. The fund was required to use TRIVIA application but remained accountable for GDPR compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed. The DPA considered nature/gravity/duration as aggravating, technical/organizational measures as aggravating, and categories of personal data affected as aggravating. No mitigating factors were mentioned.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(e) (public task). The DPA found the legal basis insufficiently predictable as it did not clearly define purposes for continued processing after program expiration, violating Articles 6(1)(e) and 6(3).
a75_case_summary: A public institution processing family assistance data continued processing after program expiration without clear legal basis. The DPA found violations of Articles 6(1)(e) juncto 6(3) (unpredictable legal basis), 13(1)(a-b) (controller/DPO identity), and 25(1-2) (insufficient confidentiality measures). The erasure request was denied due to public interest mission.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Defendant claimed legitimate interests for processing non-health data; DPA found legitimate interests valid for some purposes but invalid for staff training and CCTV storage; key reasoning was failure to demonstrate necessity and reasonable expectations
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found insurance company violated GDPR transparency and legal basis requirements in privacy statement. Company failed to demonstrate legitimate interests for staff training and CCTV storage purposes. DPA reduced fine from €50,000 to €30,000 considering some legitimate interests were valid and company made efforts to correct privacy statement.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity was aggravating; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; categories of data affected were aggravating; other factors included company's efforts to correct privacy statement as mitigating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was based on Article 6(1)(b) GDPR (contract performance). The DPA found this legal basis valid as telephone recordings were necessary for proper contract execution and quality assurance between the parties.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2020 on data subject rights – right of access;Guidelines on transparency under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA found a digital services company violated GDPR access rights by refusing to provide copies of recorded business calls, offering only on-site listening. The company claimed contract necessity for recordings but failed to facilitate proper access. The DPA upheld transparency violations regarding unclear privacy statements but rejected claims about unlawful processing basis.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included infringement seriousness and data protection measures failure. Mitigating factors included lack of intent, cooperation with authorities, and no previous infringements. Neutral factors included categories of personal data affected.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the practice of requesting and keeping identity cards as guarantee violated lawfulness and fairness principles under Article 5(1)(a), noting that withholding identity cards prevents compliance with legal obligation to carry identification and that the alternative guarantee option (€100) was not transparently communicated.
a75_case_summary: A private domain operator requested visitors' identity cards as guarantee for tool rentals. The Belgian DPA found this practice violated Article 5(1)(a) GDPR as it was unlawful (preventing compliance with legal ID carrying obligation) and unfair (alternative €100 guarantee not transparently offered). The DPA issued a warning under Article 58(2)(a) GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Defendant Y mistakenly shared complainant's personal data with federal organization Z three times while verifying social tariff eligibility. The DPA found violations of GDPR Articles 5(1)(f), 24, and 32 due to inadequate technical/organizational measures preventing unauthorized data transfers. A warning was issued as a prima facie decision, allowing defendant to present counterarguments before substantive proceedings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was lawful under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR for public authority tasks. The DPA found processing of first complainant's data lawful but processing of second complainant's data and family relationship assumptions unlawful as not necessary for public authority purposes.
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found public institution unlawfully processed personal data from National Register by mentioning second complainant's data and assuming family relationships without necessity for public authority tasks. The institution consulted register twice for waste violation proceedings against first complainant. DPA issued reprimand for Article 6 violation and warning for future compliance.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed without investigation due to insufficient evidence and low priority. Plaintiff alleged improper reference checks during recruitment process but provided only SMS screenshot as evidence. Litigation Chamber found evidence insufficient to verify authenticity and concluded complaint lacked sufficient elements for sanction.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint against Google for refusal to remove search results under right to be forgotten; Google initially refused removal request but later complied during proceedings; Dispute Chamber dismissed case due to lack of factual elements to assess potential GDPR violations
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued warning to employer for violating data minimization principle by specifying nature of dismissal (serious misconduct) in email to 20-30 staff members. Chamber found mentioning departure alone would suffice for purpose of informing employees. This is a prima facie decision allowing defendant to request substantive treatment within 30 days.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant claimed processor status, arguing it had no obligation to comply with data subject access requests. The DPA found the defendant acted as processor, not controller, as healthcare providers exclusively determined purposes and means of processing through the software platform.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA ruled on a complaint regarding right of access against Y, administrator of an online appointment software platform. The DPA found Y acted as processor, not controller, as healthcare providers exclusively determined processing purposes and means. Since processors have no direct obligation to respond to data subject access requests under GDPR, the complaint was dismissed.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The defendant claimed the line manager acted as sole controller when consulting medical records, but the DPA found the defendant remained controller and breached integrity/confidentiality principles under Article 5(1)(f) GDPR.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR;Guidelines 9/2022 on the notification of personal data breaches under the GDPR;Guidelines 01/2021 on examples regarding the notification of personal data breaches;WP250 Guidelines adopted on 3 October 2017 on the notification of personal data breaches under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: Hospital employee complained about unauthorized access to her medical records by line manager prior to dismissal. DPA found defendant remained controller despite claiming line manager acted autonomously. Breach involved health data requiring special protection. DPA issued compliance order but no fine due to early GDPR implementation context.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The municipality claimed processing was based on legal obligations under national law for marriage solemnization. The DPA found the municipality violated minimization principles by identically adopting prosecutor's advice containing criminal data of third parties without assessing necessity.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR;Opinion 03/2013 on purpose limitation
a75_case_summary: A Belgian municipality was found to violate GDPR minimization principles by identically copying a prosecutor's advice containing third-party criminal data into a marriage refusal decision. The DPA determined the municipality was controller despite claiming to merely follow prosecutor advice. The municipality had since implemented anonymization practices for third-party data in such decisions.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the criminal nature of data as aggravating and the municipality's remedial actions (implementing anonymization) as mitigating. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued prima facie decision against magazine publisher Y for failing to respond to data subject's access request regarding source of personal data used for unsolicited magazine delivery. The Disputes Chamber found potential violation of Articles 12.3, 12.4 and 15.1 GDPR and ordered compliance with access request under Article 58.2.c) GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found the controller violated data minimization principles by requiring mandatory account creation for complaint submission, though alternative channels existed but were not adequately communicated to users.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 4/2019 on Article 25 Data Protection by Design and by Default
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued warning to company Y for requiring mandatory customer account creation to file complaints, violating data minimization principles under Article 25 GDPR read with Article 5(1)(c). The company had implemented alternative complaint channels but failed to adequately communicate these options on its Finnish website. The DPA noted the company had since added guest account functionality, mitigating the violation.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the company's remedial actions (adding guest account functionality) as mitigating factors, leading to a warning rather than formal proceedings. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 01/2022 on data subject rights - Right of access
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed without technical follow-up. The Litigation Chamber found no evidence of GDPR violations as the complaint concerned professional ethics rules regarding file restitution by a lawyer, not data processing issues. The Chamber noted no GDPR-based request was made to the defendant and lacked jurisdiction over lawyer disciplinary matters or file restitution orders.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed consent for cookies but DPA found consent invalid due to pre-ticked boxes and lack of specific consent. For other processing, no valid legal basis was demonstrated.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on transparency in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2016/679;Guidelines on consent under Regulation 2016/679;Guidelines on Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: Social housing company violated multiple GDPR principles including lawfulness, transparency, and accountability. Deficiencies included inadequate privacy policies, invalid consent for cookies, insufficient data protection officer arrangements, and unlawful processing of consumption data. The DPA found serious infringements but considered mitigating factors including defendant's willingness to adapt.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Aggravating factors included nature/gravity/duration of infringements, negligent character, inadequate technical measures, categories of data affected, and non-compliance with prior orders. Mitigating factors included actions to mitigate damage, cooperation with authority, and defendant's financial situation.

a7_defendant_name: The General Commissariat for Refugees and Stateless Persons (CGRA)
a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA found no GDPR violation as the processing was conducted by employees acting under the controller's authority, not as independent controllers, and no evidence showed GDPR breaches by the controller itself.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 07/2020 on the notions of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA dismissed a complaint about an asylum officer using personal phone to photograph family members' social media pages during an asylum hearing. The DPA found the employee was not a controller but acted under the authority of CGRA, the actual controller. No GDPR violations were found as the processing occurred within CGRA's legal mission and photos were immediately deleted from the personal device.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR but the DPA found it invalid as the interests did not prevail over data subjects' rights despite being legitimate; key reasoning included lack of reasonable expectation for commercial processing of publicly available professional data.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria for the right to be forgotten in the search engine business pursuant to the GDPR;Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR
a75_case_summary: The defendant operated a healthcare professional platform processing personal data of tens of thousands of professionals without valid legal basis; The DPA found legitimate interest invalid as commercial interests didn't outweigh data subjects' rights despite public nature of data; The defendant was ordered to cease processing and fined €10,000 for violations of Articles 5(1)(a), 6(1)(f), and 12(2) with Article 17(1).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors: severity was aggravating due to scale and duration; nature was aggravating as negligent; actions to mitigate damage were mitigating; technical measures were aggravating; previous infringements were mitigating; categories of data were neutral; profit from infringement was aggravating.

a36_legal_basis_summary: Y1 claimed legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) for direct marketing. DPA found Y1 failed to demonstrate that its interests outweighed data subjects' rights, particularly regarding reasonable expectations of processing.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found Y1 SA violated GDPR Articles 5(1)(a), 6, and 24 by processing personal data for direct marketing without valid legal basis. Y1 claimed legitimate interest but failed to demonstrate its interests outweighed data subjects' rights. Processing was one-time occurrence and data was deleted.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA considered one-time nature of processing and deletion of data as mitigating factors when issuing reprimands instead of fines. Other Article 83(2) factors were not systematically discussed.

a36_legal_basis_summary: The DPA warned that if the publication relies on Article 6 GDPR bases (except consent), it must meet the necessity condition under Article 5(1)(c); if no valid lawfulness basis exists, the defendant must cease processing and potentially delete data.
a75_case_summary: Complaint regarding right to rectification of meeting minutes questioning complainant's professional qualifications. DPA found no Article 16 violation as minutes accurately reflected opinions expressed, not factual inaccuracies. Warning issued for potential Article 6 violation regarding publication lawfulness and Article 12 violation for failure to respond to data subject request.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint against appliance retailer Y regarding processing of landlord's data. Complainant purchased dishwasher, technician allegedly caused damage and sent invoice to landlord using obtained contact details. DPA found complainant lacked standing as not data subject and showed no interest acting on landlord's behalf.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA found defendant violated GDPR by continuing direct marketing emails after complainant's multiple objections. Defendant failed to comply with prior light decision ordering compliance with data subject rights. The DPA issued a reprimand and compliance orders for erasure, cessation of processing, and notification obligations.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed compliance through alternative access methods. The DPA found violations of data minimization and transparency principles due to requiring Microsoft accounts for access, processing more data than necessary through third-party involvement.
a75_case_summary: Belgian Finance Ministry required Microsoft accounts for accessing tax documentation. DPA found violations of GDPR principles 5(1)(a) and 5(1)(c) regarding transparency and data minimization, Article 35 DPIA requirement, and Articles 6/7 regarding cookie consent. Controller implemented alternative access methods during proceedings.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA discussed Article 83(2) factors briefly. Nature/gravity was aggravating due to sensitive fiscal context. Technical measures were aggravating due to inadequate safeguards. Mitigation was present due to remedial actions taken during proceedings.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint regarding electoral propaganda letters sent to seniors using municipal data. Defendant signed letter but investigation found no evidence he determined processing means or accessed municipal senior file. Case dismissed as defendant could not be qualified as controller under Article 4.7 GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed on expediency grounds as incidental to broader contractual dispute involving service provision contract termination, payment disputes, copyright issues, and threats of legal action. Litigation Chamber found intervention not strictly necessary given complexity and scale of broader conflict requiring judicial resolution. No substantive examination of GDPR violations conducted due to resource proportionality concerns.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint alleged dance association requested vaccination status for registration; defendant denied requesting this information; Litigation Chamber found insufficient evidence to prove GDPR violation; case dismissed without further action due to lack of proof.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c) based on municipal regulations, but the DPA found this invalid as the regulations did not clearly and precisely establish an obligation to process the specific data collected, particularly data concerning domiciled occupants which fell outside the taxable event.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Opinion 04/2007 on the concept of personal data;Opinion 06/2014 on the notion of legitimate interest;Guidelines on Data Protection Officers
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA issued a warning to City Y for collecting excessive personal data through tourist tax forms. The city requested names, birth dates, and entry/exit dates of all occupants including domiciled persons, violating Articles 6 (lawfulness) and 5(1)(c) (minimization) since only non-domiciled occupants were subject to the tax. The DPA noted the city had already committed to reform the forms for future tax enrollments.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: The DPA considered the defendant's commitments to reform the data collection process as a mitigating factor when issuing a warning instead of more severe sanctions. No other Article 83(2) factors were systematically discussed in this prima facie decision.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Complaint dismissed on grounds of expediency; complainant filed too soon after access request (3 days instead of waiting GDPR response period); complaint incidental to broader employment dispute with ongoing disciplinary proceedings; Litigation Chamber found insufficient efficiency justification for investigation
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA ordered defendant Y to comply with complainant's access request regarding marketing emails sent to company employees. Defendant failed to respond to access request within statutory timeframe. Decision is prima facie finding of Article 15 violation, with potential for further proceedings if defendant disputes.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) and Data Protection how to determine whether the processing is "likely to create a high risk" for the purposes of Regulation (EU) 2016/679, WP 248
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued warning to hospital for GDPR violations regarding access controls to sensitive patient data. Complaint concerned broad accessibility of sexual assault victim's medical records to hospital staff beyond treating professionals. DPA found potential breaches of security obligation (Article 32) and accountability principle (Article 5(2)).
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed processing was for journalistic purposes under freedom of expression. The DPA found the processing necessary for exercising freedom of expression and information rights under Article 17.3.a GDPR, balancing data protection rights against public interest in transparency of public officials' remuneration.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines on the implementation of the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union in the case of Google Spain and Inc. v Agencia espanola de proteccion de datos (AEPD) and Mario Consteja Gonzalez (C-131/12)
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA dismissed a complaint against Cumuleo.be regarding publication of a public official's private sector remuneration. The DPA found the processing necessary for exercising freedom of expression and information rights under Article 17.3.a GDPR, balancing data protection against public interest in transparency. The website republished publicly available mandate declarations required by Belgian law, contributing to debate on public management transparency and conflict of interest prevention.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller invoked Article 17.3.a) GDPR exception for freedom of expression and information. The DPA found the defendant rightly refused the erasure request as processing was necessary for journalistic purposes and archiving in public interest.
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2019 on the criteria for the right to be forgotten under the GDPR in the case of search engines
a75_case_summary: Complaint regarding refusal to erase personal data from press archive articles about complainant's electric scooter business. DPA found defendant rightly refused erasure request under Article 17.3.a) GDPR exception for freedom of expression and information. Balancing test favored journalistic freedom and archive integrity over data subject's right to erasure.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a7_defendant_name: FPS Finance, General Administration of the Special Tax Inspectorate
a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA dismissed complaint against tax authority for lack of jurisdiction and insufficient interest. Complainant challenged FPS Finance's use of customer data obtained from criminal file for tax valuation purposes. DPA found no jurisdiction over pre-GDPR data collection and insufficient complainant interest regarding customer data processing. Court proceedings regarding tax dispute were deemed outside DPA's jurisdiction under Article 55(3) GDPR.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller claimed legitimate interest for both transfer of membership file and marketing mailings. The DPA found legitimate interest valid for the file transfer in bankruptcy context but invalid for marketing due to transparency violations.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 04/2022 on the calculation of administrative fines under the GDPR;Opinion 06/2014 on the concept of legitimate interest of the controller
a75_case_summary: Football club acquired membership list during bankruptcy takeover and sent commercial mailings without proper transparency information. DPA found legitimate interest valid for file transfer but violated transparency principles and access rights. Fine imposed for information obligation breaches.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: DPA systematically discussed Article 83(2) factors. Nature/gravity/duration and negligence were aggravating. Cooperation and mitigation measures were mitigating. Other factors were neutral.

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: Recommendation n°1/2020 of January 17, 2020 relating to the processing of personal data for the purposes of direct marketing
a75_case_summary: A real estate agency continued sending marketing emails to a complainant despite multiple requests to be removed from their mailing list. The Belgian DPA found the defendant violated Article 21.2 GDPR by failing to honor the right to object to marketing processing. The DPA ordered the defendant to comply with the objection request within 30 days. This is a preliminary decision that could lead to further proceedings if the defendant contests it.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a75_case_summary: Belgian DPA issued warning to company Y for potential breach of Article 12.3 GDPR by failing to inform complainant about measures taken following objection to direct marketing emails. Company complied with objection request but did not provide required information about measures taken. Decision is preliminary and allows defendant to request review.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED
a74_guidelines_referenced: EDPB Guidelines 5/2020 on consent under Regulation (EU) 2016/679
a75_case_summary: The Belgian DPA dismissed a complaint filed by NOYB on behalf of a data subject due to procedural defects in the representation mandate under Article 80.1 GDPR. The DPA found NOYB artificially created the complaint through a "model case" project using interns, constituting abuse of rights and a fictitious mandate. The decision did not address substantive GDPR violations, focusing solely on the improper lodging of the complaint.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: The controller processed health data without proper legal basis. The DPA found no valid basis under Article 9(2) for communicating health information to colleagues and recording it in meeting minutes.
a74_guidelines_referenced: Guidelines 07/2020 on the concepts of controller and processor in the GDPR
a75_case_summary: A public authority director communicated an employee's health data (declared unfit for work) at a department meeting and recorded it in meeting minutes. The DPA found this constituted incompatible further processing of health data without proper legal basis under Articles 5(1)(b), 6(4) and 9(2) GDPR. As a public authority, the defendant received a reprimand but no fine.
a76_art83_weighing_summary: NOT_DISCUSSED

a36_legal_basis_summary: Controller claimed contract basis for initial processing but lacked valid basis for sharing data with third party; DPA found legitimate interest invalid due to failure of necessity and balancing tests; No consent obtained for sharing.
a75_case_summary: A fitness club employee improperly shared a member's personal data (name, address, date of birth, contact details, visit dates) with a third party who had mistakenly paid the member's subscription fees.
